attributes.title: Income Inequality and Counterfeits - Egalitarian Motives

q1.value: iPhone GooPhone mixed design HBS with Egalitarian Motives 2

q2.value: S. Wiley Wakeman, Jingshi Liu, Michael I Norton

q3.value: This is a follow up study to iPhone GooPhone mixed design HBS with Egalitarian Motives registered by Wiley Wakeman. It replicates that design with the addition of eight items, namely, the benevolent/spiteful egalitarian measures (detailed below). We also took out the social dominance orientation measure, and the counterfeit acceptance/prevalence measures, as individual difference measures from the study.

q4.value: Under high (vs. low) income inequality, consumers are more likely to perceive counterfeit (vs. genuine) products to have greater egalitarian value. The egalitarian value in turn positively affects consumers' attitudes toward counterfeits. The effect of egalitarian value on counterfeit attitudes should be independent of the hedonic, utilitarian, status signaling, and economic values of a counterfeit.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: 2 between-subject (video: income inequality, neutral) X 2 within-subject (phone: counterfeit, genuine) mixed design.

q9.value: Participants are randomly assigned to one of the 2 (video: income inequality, neutral). In the income inequality condition, they watch a video about wealth inequality in the US. In the neutral video, they watch a video about brain science.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: We will post the study on MTurk. Participants will receive monetary rewards for their participation. MTurk workers who are located in the U.S., with a 95% HIT acceptance rate are eligible to participate. Before they can start the study, they must pass two screening questions to make sure they are not robots. One question requires basic human logic and common sense (e.g., up is to down as left is to ___?) and the other question is a Qualtrics Catcha. We will include a comprehension check for the video prime in the study. Data from participants who fail this check will be excluded from analyses. We will use scripts to exclude MTurk workers who have completed the study before, but will also check for redundant MTurk IDs and exclude these participants.

q14.value: Based on the results from our previous studies, a cell size of 150 is pre-determined.

q15.value: We will collect data until the sample size is met.

question.value: Video prime: participants watch a video either about income inequality in the US, or a neutral video about brain science.

Participants report the following perceived values of both a genuine iPhone, and a counterfeit GooPhone: hednic value, utilitarian value, economic value, social signaling value, and egalitarian value. Additionally we will test for egalitarian value using the dominance and antiegalitarian routes descried in Ho et al., (2015, JPSP - The nature of social domiance). In addition, we will test for two types of egalitarian values: 
Egalitarian Benevolence:
1.	Allows those who are poorer feel like they have more
2.	Brings up those who have less
3.	Improves the lives of those who have less
4.	Helps those who are poorer feel like they are equal with others
 
Egalitarian Spite:
1.	Puts the rich “in their place”
2.	Helps teach the rich a lesson
3.	Makes life fair by getting back at those who keep people at the bottom down
4.	Helps to spite those who are richer

 Additional dependent variables: They report the extent to which they would like to purchase the phone. They also complete their demographic information.

All the scale measures with more than one item will be combined into an index by averaging the scores of all items in the scale. Before creating the index, we will first reversed code the items that are phrased reservedly. We will also test the reliability of the scale before creating the index. A chrombach's alpha = .7 is considered acceptable.

1.	Separate ANOVAs on each of the dependent measures will be conducted, using the video prime as a factor as well as simple t-tests when no covariates [or controls] are needed for analysis. We compute the difference score for each dependent variable between the iPhone and the GooPhone. 2) We will test parallel mediating effect of the different relative perceived values (hedonic value, utilitarian value, economic value, social signaling value, and egalitarian value) on the effect of video prime on purchase intention toward counterfeits.

q20.value: Skewed dependent variables will be log transformed.

q21.value: p= .1 is marginally significant. p = .05 is significant. We will test simple effects of any interactions that are marginally significant.

q22.value: Data from participants who fail the attention check and the comprehension check will be excluded from analyses. Any participants who have already completed studies in this project will be excluded.

q23.value: Participants with incomplete data will be excluded from analyses.

attributes.title: The political effects of opioid addiction frames

q1.value: The political effects of opioid addiction frames

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: Given increasing opioid use and overdose deaths in the United States, it is important to address questions about public opinion on policy responses to opioid abuse. One potentially important aspect shaping the public response to these overdose deaths is race. While the media portrays opioid use as a problem that primarily affects whites, it is also becoming increasingly common in minority communities. How do frames for opioid addiction influence political views on this issue? To answer this question, we will conduct a randomized experiment, varying the racial and valence frames of hypothetical news articles about opioid addiction in the United States. We will analyze the impact of these frames on attitudes about drug addiction and whether it should be addressed with punitive or treatment-focused government action. See the attached pre-analysis plan for more background information about this study.

q16.value: We will test the following key hypotheses in this study. See the attached pre- analysis plan for additional sub-hypotheses and detailed descriptions of the quantities of interest and the associated measures. Valence hypotheses: Sympathy hypothesis: The valence approach predicts that favorable news coverage will generate sympathy regardless of target race. This hypothesis compares the no-story baseline against each of the three sympathetic conditions. Antipathy hypothesis: Conversely, the same logic predicts that unfavorable coverage will generate antipathy regardless of target race. This hypothesis compares the no-story baseline against each condition conveying antipathy. Racialized hypotheses: Racial sympathy hypothesis: The racialized hypothesis predicts that favorable coverage will generate sympathy along a gradient of racial hierarchy from white to no-race to black targets. When race is unspecified sympathy will be in between. This hypothesis entails comparing the three racial groups to each other. Racial antipathy hypothesis: The racialized hypothesis likewise predicts that unfavorable coverage will generate a gradient of antipathy by race, with more antipathy when targeting blacks than no-race than whites. When race is unspecified antipathy will be in between. This hypothesis also compares the racial groups to each other. Racial moderator effect hypothesis: The effects of these racial hypotheses will be stronger for respondents with negative racial predispositions. Ideological null effect hypothesis: The effects of these racial hypotheses will be weakly moderated by respondent ideology and partisanship, or none at all, accounting for racial predispositions.

q17.value: These hypotheses will be tested using regression analyses. See the attached pre- analysis plan for a detailed overview of the regression equations and proposed analyses.

q27.value: The study will be implemented by a survey firm.

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

other.value:
Additional variables for possible exploratory analyses:
-Child sex
-Child age
-SES (e.g., parental education / income)
-Trial (first, second)

Another possible analysis will be to conduct an analysis of infants who have two usable test trials AND infants who only have a usable test trial on the FIRST test trial (i.e., their second test trial resulted in their exclusion). This analysis would be to determine whether attrition in the second test trial is related to overall changes in the pattern of results.

sample.value:
Our ideal sample size is 80 infants with 2 useable test trials (20 per belief X final object combination: TB-DesirableObject, TB-BoringObject, FB-DesirableObject, FB-BoringObject, equal numbers of female and male infants in each combination), which will have sufficient power (B-1 = .95) to detect a medium effect size in a within-subjects design (partial-eta squared = .2). However, given the likelihood of attrition and exclusions due to the criteria outlined in this pre-registration, we anticipate having to collect more than 80 infants to obtain 80 subjects with 2 useable test trials. If our total attrition rate using the pre-registered exclusion criteria exceeds 50%, we will revisit the design and, if necessary, resubmit a pre-registration with updated information. 

However, in the specific case that if infants are being excluded only for dropping out in the second test trial, yet have a usable first test trial, we will implement a between-subjects design and analysis (see analyses section).

analyses.value:
The data will be analyzed using a repeated-measures mixed effects model specified with a normal distribution, a diagonal link, and a diagonal covariance matrix with final object and belief as between-subjects factors, emotion as a within-subjects factor, and interactions of Final Object × Belief, Final Object × Emotion, Belief × Emotion, and Final Object × Belief × Emotion.

Analyses will be conducted to examine potential fatigue effects of having two test trials. These will consist of separate models for final object with the main effect and interactions of trial order with belief and emotion. If it appears that infants are exhibiting the predicted effects in the first trial, with the second trial looking times not differing, we will also conduct a between-subjects analyses (described below).

The between-subjects analysis using only the first test trial of data and will examine a full factorial model of final object, belief, and emotion.

outliers.value:
Infants will be excluded (and a replacement infant of the same gender will be recruited and tested in the same condition) for the following reasons:
-Fussiness 
-Sleepiness
-Parental interference
-External distraction (e.g., a noise from outside the room distracts the infant)
-Equipment failure
-Infants with looking times that are 3 SD greater than the group mean
-infants that did not pay sufficient attention to the familiarization trials (meaning that the infant is unaware of E1’s preferences)
-infants that did not pay sufficient attention during the video portion of the test trials (meaning that the infant is unaware of the objects being switched or whether E1 was in the room or not during the switch, etc.)

dependent.value: The primary dependent variable will be looking time during the still frame image at the end of the test trials, as measured using a Tobii Pro Spectrum 1200hz eye-tracker.

conditions.value:
Descriptions of each trial are below:

Preference trial: 
The emoter (E1) is sitting at a table. A second experimenter (E2) enters the room from behind a room divider with a transparent bag containing two objects: a desirable object (an attractive 12 cm X 12 cm blue ball with sparkly blue tentacles) and an undesirable object (a 12 cm x 8 cm x 3 cm black rubber rectangle). E2 removes each object from the bag and places one to the left of E1 and one to the right of E1. E2 then exits the room. E1 leans over and looks at the object on her left and facially and vocally expresses the corresponding emotion (desirable object = positive interest; undesirable interest = aversion/distaste). E1 then leans over to the object on her right and facially and vocally expresses the corresponding emotion. E1 then repeats these actions/emotions a second time. 

All infants will receive two preference trials: one with the desirable object on the left, and one with the desirable object on the right. The order of these trials will be counterbalanced across infants via random assignment.

Test trial: 
E1 is sitting at the same table with an opaque lidded box. She opens the box and turns it over so that the viewer can see that the container is empty. E2 enters the room carrying a transparent bag containing the two objects and sets it on the table. E2 opens the box and sets the lid on the table. E2 then opens the bag, removes an object (desirable or undesirable), places it in the box, and replaces the lid, setting the box on the center of the table. A doorbell then chimes and E1 stands up to open a door and exits, closing the door behind her. The subsequent events differ by condition

In the false-belief condition, E2 then opens the box and sets the lid on the table, removes the ball from the box, and switches it with the rectangle in the bag. E2 then closes the box, sets it back on the table, and exits the room behind the room divider. E1 then returns to the room, sits down, and picks up the box, but does not open it. The video then cuts to a close-up of E1’s head and torso. E1 expresses either excitement or disappointment while holding and looking at the box. 

In the true-belief condition, E1 immediately returns to the room after closing the door, sits down, and watches E2 switch the objects and exit the room. E1 then picks up the box and expresses excitement or disappointment.

Equal numbers of infants will be randomly assigned to one of four combinations of belief condition (false-belief, true-belief) and initial box contents (undesirable first, desirable first). Each infant will view two test trials differing in the emotion E1 displays (excitement, disappointment). For half of the infants, the disappointment trial is congruent with E1's belief (i.e. true-belief desirable first, false-belief undesirable first) and for the other half the excitement trial is congruent with E1's belief (i.e. true-belief undesirable first, false-belief desirable first). The order of the test trials will be counterbalanced across infants.

hypothesis.value: Previous research has demonstrated that infants are sensitive to others' emotions and the events leading up to an emotional reaction (e.g., expressing sadness after achieving a goal; Skerry & Spelke, 2014). Additionally, research has indicated that infants are also sensitive to others' beliefs and will look longer when an agent performs a goal-directed action that is incongruent with their belief state (e.g., Onishi & Baillargeon, 2005). Recent research has indicated that infants are sensitive to the emotions an agent expresses after that agent discovers that they were mistaken (Scott, 2017). However, to date, research has not yet investigated whether infants are also sensitive to the emotional expressions of other agents who possess ongoing false beliefs (e.g., predicting that an agent who falsely believes that an empty box contains her prized toy should express happiness when given the box). Thus, this study will examine whether infants possess the ability to make false-emotion attributions. We predict that infants who expect an agent to respond emotionally in accordance with their beliefs will look longer when the experimenter expresses an emotion incongruent with her belief.

study_type_other.value: VOE criteria for ending trials: during the still-frame portions of the trial, the trial will end if (a) the infant looks away for 2 consecutive seconds after having looked for 2 cumulative seconds or (b) the infant looks for a total of 60 cumulative seconds.

attributes.title: Shared and unique associations between maladaptive traits and variability in interpersonal behavior, perception, and affect

q1.value: Shared and unique associations between maladaptive traits and variability in interpersonal behavior, perception, and affect

q2.value: Whitney R. Ringwald, Aidan G.C. Wright, Alexandre Dombrovski, Michael Hallquist

q3.value:
Shortcomings of categorical personality disorder diagnoses have launched efforts to develop empirical models that better reflect individual differences in personality functioning.  Quantitative approaches have been used to identify covariation among personality disorder symptoms and have consistently recovered five maladaptive trait dimensions: Antagonism, Detachment, Disinhibition, Negative Affectivity, and Psychoticism (Krueger 2012; O’Connor, 2005; Widiger & Simonsen, 2005).  In contrast to viewing personality disorders as distinct, categorical entities, each trait represents a different characteristic style of impairment spanning a continuous range of possible severity.  As a testament to the paradigm shift towards dimensional trait models, one instantiation appears in the most recent Diagnostic and Statistical Manual for Mental Disorders, 5th Edition, Section III (DSM-5; American Psychiatric Association, 2013) and a nearly identical framework has been proposed for the upcoming version of the ICD-11 (World Health Organization, 2018).  Trait models have gained traction because they not only outperform categorical personality disorder diagnoses psychometrically (Al-Dajani, Gralnick, & Bagby, 2016; Zimmerman et al., 2019), they also align with what is observed clinically.
     According to many clinical theories, all personality pathology involves impairment in capacities necessary to satisfy fundamental needs for agency and interpersonal relatedness that is expressed in different, stylistic ways (Kernberg, 1984; Livesley & Jang, 2000; Pincus, 2005).  Consistent with this theoretical structure, all maladaptive traits share common pathological features which are reflected statistically in their shared variance (i.e., positive correlations).  In clinical presentation, these features are indistinguishable; thus, characterizing traits as amalgams of general and specific variance is practical for diagnostic purposes (Hopwood, 2018).  To accommodate this complexity, maladaptive traits models have been intentionally constructed to depart from a simple structure to allow interstitial symptoms (Krueger & Markon, 2014). For the purposes of articulating and validating the conceptual model, however, it is necessary to clarify the nature of what is shared among traits and what is unique about them.
     The majority of research evaluating the validity of maladaptive trait models has not statistically separated these sources of variance, so the nomological network of general and specific trait features are not well-defined.  Research looking at these components independently, using different analytic approaches, have demonstrated that general and specific factors correlate differentially with external criteria (Ringwald et al., 2019; Williams, Scalco, & Simms, 2018) and have distinct developmental trajectories (Hopwood et al., 2011; Wright et al., 2015; 2016).  Other studies have shown specific variance in maladaptive traits provide unique information about outcomes measures, but without examining the complementary shared variance removed from these analyses (i.e., general personality pathology; Creswell et al., 2016; Few et al., 2013; Fowler et al., 2017).  Overall, this work supports the match between theoretical and empirical models, and has helped conceptualize the structure of personality pathology.  
     However, studies of general and specific maladaptive trait features have primarily examined cross-sectional associations.  Cross-sectional methods are not well suited to measure the most clinically definitive aspects of personality pathology: the moment-to-moment patterns of perceiving and responding to situations, particularly interpersonal situations (Sullivan, 1953; Pincus, Hopwood, & Wright, 2018).  Ambulatory assessment (AA), which entails intensive, repeated assessment of an individual over days or weeks, has been used to closely track these dynamics in near real time and with greater ecological validity compared to cross-sectional measures (Shiffman, Stone, & Hufford, 2008; Trull & Ebner-Priemer, 2013).  An intellectual advance enabled by AA has been measurement of temporal variability in affect, behavior, and cognitions.  Variability over time is a pattern consistent with processes of dysregulation that makeup the foundation of clinical conceptualizations of personality pathology (Trull et al., 2008). Most AA research on variability in personality pathology has focused on DSM-defined borderline personality disorder given the criterion for the diagnosis (e.g., affect lability, impulsive behavior; APA, 2013).  As expected clinically, it has been demonstrated that borderline personality disorder symptoms are associated with elevated variability in affect (Ebner-Priemer, 2007; Hepp et al., 2018; Jahng et al., 2011; Mniemne et al., 2018; Santangelo, Bohus & Ebner-Priemer, 2014; Trull et al., 2008), interpersonal behaviors (Russell et al., 2007), and self-esteem (Santangelo, 2017; Zeigler-Hill & Abraham, 2006).
     Despite the value of this research for tethering nomothetic constructs to clinically relevant processes, it has almost exclusively been in relation to categorical models.  As research and clinical practice transitions to using empirically-based models, it is an open question whether and how variability fits into a dimensional trait framework.  Only three studies have used AA in the context of maladaptive traits.  In an undergraduate sample, it was found that maladaptive traits, adjusting for their shared variance, associate differentially with increased average daily interpersonal and self functioning (Roche, 2018).  Two studies have examined day-to-day variability in personality pathology symptoms and found contradictory results.   In a clinical sample, maladaptive traits were uniquely associated with more variability in daily personality disorder symptomology (Wright & Simms, 2016), while in another study using an undergraduate sample, traits were associated with less variability in daily personality functioning (Roche, Jacobson, & Pincus, 2016).  Both of these studies, like Roche (2018), found all traits were associated with more overall dysfunction and distress from day-to-day.  This work is a critical step towards linking maladaptive traits with pathological processes, but the daily sampling schedule is not optimal for capturing many key manifestations of personality pathology that occur at the scale of interactions within a day.
     For instance, consider an individual who tends to view others in an extreme, all-or-nothing manner.  During one interaction with her romantic partner, she is intensely affectionate and subservient. Later in the day, she perceives rejection in her partners’ benign side remark and angrily lashes out at him.  Or consider another individual with self-esteem contingent others’ views of him such that he fluctuates between feeling grandiose and defensively hostile depending on the perceived admiration of others around him at any given moment.  In clinical theories, these dynamics are explained in terms of insecure attachments (Bateman & Fonagy, 2004), cognitive distortions (Beck, Davis, & Freeman, 2014), maladaptive schemas (Young, 1994), or unintegrated object representations (Clarkin, Yeomans, & Kernberg, 1999), and are central to a conceptual, mechanistic model of personality pathology.
     Our previous work is the first to our knowledge to investigate momentary dynamics in relation to maladaptive traits (OSF: https://osf.io/bnsug/).  In a pre-registered replication using two adult samples, we examined associations between maladaptive traits and AA-derived estimates of average positive and negative affect, interpersonal behavior, and perception of others’ behavior across interactions, as well as variability in each of these outcomes.  Interpersonal behavior of self and others was operationalized by dimensions of affiliation (i.e., warm to cold) and dominance (i.e., dominant to submissive). In addition to zero-order associations, we also looked at associations with shared and unique trait variance to distinguish general and specific interpersonal patterns.  We found that general personality pathology (i.e. shared variance between maladaptive traits) and trait style (i.e., trait variance adjusted for covariance with other traits) had theoretically-consistent associations with interpersonal variables.  General personality pathology was characterized by having more distressing and less positive, affiliative interactions overall, as well as more variability in dominant behavior, perceived dominance, and negative affect.  Specific trait styles were associated differentially to average momentary affects and behaviors, but less so to variability.  Taken together, this study showed the structural independence of general and specific features and reinforced their validity for predicting functioning in everyday life.
     The current study will replicate and extend our previous work in two, important ways.  We will use two samples representing a range of personality functioning needed to properly test a dimensional trait model, but are also enriched with personality pathology to promote generalizability to clinical populations (Stanton et al., 2020).  In addition to sample composition, this study will build on our previous study by measuring traits with two different instruments (i.e., Personality Inventory for DSM-5 [PID-5; Krueger et al., 2012], Computerized Adaptive Test of Personality Disorder Static Form [CAT-PD-SF; Simms et al., 2011]) to provide convergent validity between methods.
     To establish an overall clinical picture of each trait, and to provide a basis of comparison for multivariate models, we will examine zero-order associations between traits and each of the momentary variables.  Then, to clarify which features reflect general personality pathology and which are indicative of specific style, we will look at associations with all trait’s shared and unique variance.  By connecting momentary interpersonal patterns with total, shared, and unique variance in maladaptive traits we will provide several vantage points to evaluate a general and specific model of personality pathology.

question.value:
The data that will be used were not collected for the purpose of this specific study but are derived from two broader studies.  Thus, the sampling approach and some of the measures used are not relevant to the current analysis so are not described in great detail here. 

Sample 1 (S1)
     311 community members were recruited through posted flyers for a study of personality, daily stress, and social interactions.  For inclusion, participants had to be between the ages of 18 and 40 and were not currently receiving treatment for psychosis or a psychotic disorder.
Preliminary screening was used to recruit a gender-balanced sample and to ensure adequate representation of a range of personality pathology and interpersonal problems.  The sample was also selected to balance individuals who had received recent mental health treatment within the past year with those who had not.  Individuals were pre-screened using items from the Inventory of Interpersonal Problems (Morse & Pilkonis, 2007) and were recruited in an approximately 1-1-1 representation of low, moderate, and high levels of interpersonal difficulties within gender, treatment status, and the overall sample.  See Figure 1 for a graphical representation of this recruitment strategy.
     Participation in this study involved completing a battery of baseline assessments in one laboratory session followed by an AA protocol.  All participants received $50 for the baseline session.  Those who answered 90% or greater of the surveys during the AA protocol earned an additional $110 (14-day ambulatory assessment) or $160 (21-day ambulatory assessment).  This amount was prorated by week for those who completed less than 90% of the surveys overall, with surveys completed in later weeks of the study valued higher in the prorated compensation model.  Final payment was contingent upon return of the Fitbit Blaze (and, if applicable, the laboratory-owned smartphone). Additionally, for each 100 participants, a drawing was conducted for an iPad Mini.  Chances of winning increased with the number of surveys answered. 
     During the baseline portion of the study, participants completed a clinical interview and a battery of self-report measures.  Only self-report measures from the baseline assessment will be used for this study.  Following the assessment battery, participants were provided instruction from a research assistant regarding the AA procedures and the required smartphone applications were installed on their phone. For this study, only data collected through the MetricWire application will be used.  Most participants used their own Android or iOS smartphone for completing the AA surveys, however a limited number of laboratory-owned Android smartphones were available for individuals without compatible devices.
AAs typically began the day after the baseline assessment.  The length of assessment period was initially set at 21 days but was later shortened to 14 days.  Surveys were administered through the MetricWire smartphone application.  The AA protocol included surveys at the beginning and end of day as well as random prompt surveys.  A subset of participants received experimental micro surveys, and some participants had an application installed on their smartphones that collected sensor data.  For this study, only data from the random prompts will be used, so the other components of the protocol will not be described further.
Randomly-initiated survey prompts were received through push notifications sent by the MetricWire application.  Six surveys were delivered per day within an approximately 12-hour time window corresponding to the participants’ waking hours.  Blocked random intervals were set so that a minimum of 90 minutes passed between surveys and participants were given 20 minutes to respond to each one.  Each participant completed an average of 68.6 (SD = 20.92) of these surveys.
     At each random prompt, participants were asked whether or not three types of significant events had occurred since the previous survey: stressful, unpleasant, and pleasant.  For each event indicated, participants answered a series of questions including whether any interpersonal interaction was involved.  Thus, 0-3 events could be reported on during each survey.  If any type of event did not occur, the survey ended.  In this study, we will only use responses to surveys including an interaction.  Each event reported per survey will be considered a separate interaction.  
     Interactions were defined as real-time, direct conversations between the participant and one or more other individuals that last for at least five minutes.  These could include in-person, voice, video, and text-based conversations.  For each interaction, participants reported on their own affects and behaviors, and the behaviors of the person they interacted with.  If part of a group interaction, participants were instructed to report on how others behaved on average.  

Sample 2 (S2)
     This sample consists of a case-control subsample of participants drawn from a longitudinal study examining suicidal behavior in relation to borderline personality disorder (BPD).  Participants for the study were recruited from inpatient and outpatient clinics as well as from the surrounding community by advertisement.  For inclusion, participants had to be between the ages of 18 and 45.  Exclusion criteria included lifetime diagnosis of any psychotic or bipolar disorder, clinical evidence of organic brain disease, physical disorders or treatments with known psychiatric consequence (e.g., lupus, steroids), or an IQ < 70 confirmed by assessment in the study.
     The subsample used for the current study (N = 197) participated in an AA protocol, and were selected to represent the four groups identified in the overall sample (described below).  The majority of participants in the subsample meet diagnostic criteria for BPD.  The diagnosis of BPD was determined by standardized semi-structured diagnostic interviews (International Personality Disorders Examination [IPDE; Loranger, 1994] and the Diagnostic Interview for Borderlines-revised [Zanarini et al., 1989]) conducted by masters-level research clinicians.  Diagnoses were confirmed in a consensus conference by raters and two research psychiatrists using all available data, including medical records where available.  All clinical interviews were completed during a baseline assessment.  
     Each participant diagnosed with BPD was further stratified into three groups based on the lethality of reported suicide attempts.  Attempters were defined by a score > 1 (n = 107) on the Beck Lethality Scale, high-lethality attempters by a score >3 (n = 52), and the remaining were non-attempters (n = 67). The control group (n = 75) were required to have no lifetime Axis I or II diagnoses determined on the IPDE or Structured Clinical Interview for DSM-IV, respectively.  
Self-reported maladaptive traits were added to the protocol in 2017.  Thus, for some participants in the sub-sample used in this study, traits were assessed at baseline.  For others who had been participating in the study longer, maladaptive traits were assessed at a follow-up visit.
     All participants in the subsample completed a 21-day AA protocol using a smartphone provided by the study.  The protocol included beginning and end of day assessments, random surveys, and micro surveys.  Only data from the random surveys will be used for this study.  Like S2, six random prompt surveys were delivered each day by push notifications from the MetricWire application.  In each of these surveys, participants indicated whether or not an interaction lasting at least ten minutes had occurred.  When an interaction was reported, participants rated their own affects and behaviors, and the behaviors of the person they interacted with.

q13.value:
Consistent with a dimensional model, all participants regardless of diagnostic status or level of pathology will be considered in our analyses.  This will ensure adequate representation of varying levels of personality pathology.
To increase the reliability of our AA measurements, we will exclude participants from analysis that report fewer than ten interactions over the course of the AA protocol.  For S1, each separate event including an interaction will be counted (i.e., multiple interactions per survey are possible).  As a result, the final sample size for S1 is 297 and 182 for S2.

q14.value:
For S1, sample size was determined primarily by the desire to achieve stable estimates of effects rather than power to detect any specific effect size in the population, as well as the ability to detect small effects that are consistent with the average effect in the published personality and social psychological literature.  Recent work showing that correlation estimates of this size begin to stabilize when sample sizes approach N = 250 (Schönbrodt & Perugini, 2013).  Therefore, a minimum sample size of 250 was selected for the most conservative modeling situations of interest, which was establishing between-person associations.  To adjust for expected exclusion due to low participation rates in ~10% of participants, the target sample size was N > 300.
For S2, power calculations were based on goals of the parent study to detect the cross-level interaction of group as a moderator of within-person associations between momentary variables.  Informed by comparable AA studies, it was determined that an average of 52 participants per group (i.e., BPD non-attempters, attempters, high-lethality attempters, and controls) would result in a power of >.99 to detect small, between-group effects.

question.value:
Maladaptive traits
     In S1, the Computerized Adaptive Test of Personality Disorder – Static Form (CAT-PD-SF; Simms, 2013) was used to assess maladaptive traits.  The CAT-PD-SF is a self-report measure consisting of 216 items derived from the larger CAT-PD item pool (Simms et al., 2011).  Items are rated on a 5-point Likert scale (0 – Very Untrue of Me; 1 – Moderately Untrue of Me; 2 – Neither True nor Untrue of Me; 3 – Moderately True of Me; 4 – Very True of Me).  The CAT-PD-SF can be used to calculate 33 maladaptive traits: Affective Lability, Anger, Anhedonia, Anxiousness, Callousness, Cognitive Problems, Depressiveness, Domineering, Emotional Detachment, Exhibitionism, Fantasy Proneness, Grandiosity, Health Anxiety, Hostile Aggression, Irresponsibility, Manipulativeness, Mistrust, Non-Perseverance, Non-Planfulness, Norm Violation, Peculiarity, Perfectionism, Relationship Insecurity, Rigidity, Risk Taking, Romantic Disinterest, Rudeness, Self-Harm, Social Withdrawal, Submissiveness, Unusual Beliefs, Unusual Experiences, Workaholism.   
     In S2, maladaptive traits were assessed using The Personality Inventory for the DSM-5 provided by the American Psychiatric Association (Krueger et al., 2012).  It is comprised of 220 items rated on a four-point Likert scale (0—Very False/ Often False; 1 – Sometimes/ Somewhat False; 2—Sometimes/ Somewhat True; 3—Very True or Often True).  Items are used to generate dimensional scores for 25 narrow trait facets. Corresponding facets (3 per trait) can then be averaged to assess broader trait domains of Negative Affect, Detachment, Antagonism, Disinhibition, and Psychoticism (see Table 1).

Momentary affect
     In both samples, momentary affect was measured using emotion adjectives derived from the Positive and Negative Affect Schedule (Watson, Clark & Tellegen, 1988).  In the S1 AA protocol, participants rated their affect during stressful, unpleasant, and pleasant events involving interpersonal interactions (e.g., “How ADJECTIVE did you feel during this [stressful] event?”).  The adjectives Confident and Happy were used for positive affect (PA) and Angry, Nervous, and Sad were used for negative affect (NA).  Affect was indicated on a slider scale from 0 (Not at All) to 100 (Extremely) for each adjective.
     In S2 participants, participants rated their affect during interactions (i.e., “How ADJECTIVE did you feel during this interaction?”).  The adjectives Happy, Excited, and Content were used to measured PA, and NA was measured using the adjectives Angry, Nervous, Sad, and Irritated.  In this sample, affect was rated on a 5-point Likert scale (1 – Very Slightly or Not at all, 2 – A Little; 3 – Moderately; 4 – Quite a Bit; 5 – A great deal).

Momentary interpersonal behavior/ perception of others’ behavior
     Interpersonal behavior was measured identically in both samples.  Participants were prompted to “Please rate how the OTHER PERSON BEHAVED toward you during the interaction” and “Please rate YOUR BEHAVIOR toward the other person during the interaction.”  For both self and other, Dominance (“Accommodating/ Submissive/ Timid” to “Assertive/ Dominant/ Controlling”) and Affiliation (“Cold/ Distant/Hostile” to “Warm/ Friendly/ Caring”) were rated on 101-point slider scales (-50 to +50).

Covariates
     Age and gender of participants will be included as covariates at the between-person level in all analyses.
     Day of week and number of hours in study will be included as covariates at the within-person level in all analyses.  Day of week is dummy coded such that 1=weekend (Saturday, Sunday) and 0=weekday.  Day of study is centered at the average mid-point of the respective study.

Maladaptive traits
     In the PID-5, trait facet scales are averaged to produce the five trait domain scores.  The CAT-PD-SF, on the other hand, was designed to measure 33 narrow traits rather than the five broader domains of interest to this study.  To calculate trait domain-level scores, and to remain consistent across samples, CAT-PD-SF scales that are conceptually comparable to PID-5 facet scales will used to assess the five maladaptive traits.  
     For most PID-5 facets there was a clear corollary in the CAT-PD-SF.  The only exception is for calculating Antagonism, there is not a distinct Deceitfulness scale in the CAT-PD-SF. We will calculate Antagonism with the CAT-PD-SF two ways: 1. Using only the two scales that directly relate to the PID-5 scales (Manipulativeness and Grandiosity) and 2. Using Exhibitionism along with the other two Antagonism scales. 
     The corresponding scales used to calculate each trait are shown in Table 1.  For the CAT-PD-SF, there are six items per trait scale and for the PID-5 there are eight items per facet scale.  Scales are calculated by taking the average of the corresponding items in both instruments.  Then, the three corresponding traits (for the CAT-PD-SF) or facets (PID-5), shown in Table 1, are averaged to produce a score for each of the five maladaptive traits we will use as predictors in our analyses. 

Momentary affect
     Variables from the AA assessments will be indexed using multi-level structural equation modeling (MSEM) which will be mentioned here and described in greater detail in the analysis plan.
     Prior to MSEM, in both samples, adjectives corresponding to PA/NA for each survey will be averaged to produce a single, occasion-level (i.e., interaction) score for each.  Each individual’s average affect across interactions will be estimated using random intercepts for PA/NA.     Variability in affect across interactions will be estimated as the residual, within-person variance for PA/NA.

Momentary interpersonal behavior/perception of others’ behaviors
     Like affect, in both samples, average affiliative and dominant behavior of self and other across interactions will be estimated using random intercepts and within-person residual variance will be used to estimate variability in interpersonal behavior and perception.

Main Analyses

All MSEM models will be conducted in Mplus Version 8.4 (2019).  Syntax for models are provided on the OSF page for this study.

     Using this method, total variance in the observed measures of interpersonal behavior, perception, and affect was decomposed into within- and between-person latent variables.  In MSEM, both outcomes and predictors have both within- and between-person variance.  In addition, within-person (i.e., Level 1) residuals were modeled as heterogenous across individuals (i.e., Level 2 units).  This enables the residual coefficients to vary between individuals (i.e., individual differences in level of variability) and become outcomes at the between-person level (i.e., to examine trait predictors of variability).  Residuals can be interpreted as the individual’s variability around their own mean over time and individual differences in the random intercept reflect person-specific averages.  

     First, we will examine associations with total trait variance and each of the outcome variables in a series of zero-order models.  One momentary variable at a time will be regressed on each trait entered separately as a between-person predictor.  To evaluate unique associations, we will regress each momentary variable on all traits simultaneously at the between-person level.  Finally, we will estimate a latent variable from the shared variance among all traits at the between-person level.  Each momentary variable will then be regressed on this latent variable, reflecting general personality pathology.

     Bayesian estimation will be used because it allows modeling of heterogeneity in residual variances of outcome variables at the within-person level.  No prior information about parameter values will be specified (i.e., we used non-informative/diffuse priors that are the default in Mplus).

     To account for potential effects of time trends on behavior and affect, which could affect individual differences in variance, the effect of outcome variables (i.e., interpersonal behavior and affect) regressed on day of week and study day will be included at the within-person level. These effects will be estimated as random. By detrending the data in this way, the residual variances can be more readily interpreted as “true” variability rather than normative shifts in behavior and affect such as a spike in positive emotions over the weekend.  Due to concerns about the dependency of variable means and variability (Baird et al., 2006), we will adjust for their association by regressing within-person residual variance of the outcome variables on the person-specific mean of the same outcome variable. 

Replication Evaluation
To evaluate the extent to which effects replicated across samples, we will interpret overlapping 95% credibility intervals.

q20.value: As noted above, within-person assessed variables will be decomposed into within and between-person variance components. This is akin to person-mean centering the within-person variables and including their averages at the between-person level.

q21.value: Inferences will be based on point estimates drawn from their posterior distribution and associated 95% credibility intervals.  We will consider coefficients in which the credibility interval does not include zero to be significantly different from the null hypothesis.

q22.value: As previously noted, we will exclude participants from analysis that report fewer than 10 interactions over the course of the AA protocol to increase the reliability of our AA indices.

q23.value: Missing data will be assumed to be missing at random, so all available information will be used to estimate model parameters.  It is assumed that missingness is a function of variables included in the model.

q24.value: As noted in the hypotheses section, in the zero-order models associations between traits and average dominant behavior, perceived dominance, and variability in affiliative behavior, perceived affiliation, positive and negative affect will be exploratory.  In the specific trait variance models, associations between traits and average dominant behavior, perceived dominance, and variability in all criterion variables will be exploratory.  In the latent variable models, associations with average dominant behavior and perceived dominance, and associations with variability in affiliative behavior, perceived affiliation, and perceived dominance will be exploratory.

registration_responses.q1: Shared and unique associations between maladaptive traits and variability in interpersonal behavior, perception, and affect
registration_responses.q2: Whitney R. Ringwald, Aidan G.C. Wright, Alexandre Dombrovski, Michael Hallquist
registration_responses.q3:
Shortcomings of categorical personality disorder diagnoses have launched efforts to develop empirical models that better reflect individual differences in personality functioning.  Quantitative approaches have been used to identify covariation among personality disorder symptoms and have consistently recovered five maladaptive trait dimensions: Antagonism, Detachment, Disinhibition, Negative Affectivity, and Psychoticism (Krueger 2012; O’Connor, 2005; Widiger & Simonsen, 2005).  In contrast to viewing personality disorders as distinct, categorical entities, each trait represents a different characteristic style of impairment spanning a continuous range of possible severity.  As a testament to the paradigm shift towards dimensional trait models, one instantiation appears in the most recent Diagnostic and Statistical Manual for Mental Disorders, 5th Edition, Section III (DSM-5; American Psychiatric Association, 2013) and a nearly identical framework has been proposed for the upcoming version of the ICD-11 (World Health Organization, 2018).  Trait models have gained traction because they not only outperform categorical personality disorder diagnoses psychometrically (Al-Dajani, Gralnick, & Bagby, 2016; Zimmerman et al., 2019), they also align with what is observed clinically.
     According to many clinical theories, all personality pathology involves impairment in capacities necessary to satisfy fundamental needs for agency and interpersonal relatedness that is expressed in different, stylistic ways (Kernberg, 1984; Livesley & Jang, 2000; Pincus, 2005).  Consistent with this theoretical structure, all maladaptive traits share common pathological features which are reflected statistically in their shared variance (i.e., positive correlations).  In clinical presentation, these features are indistinguishable; thus, characterizing traits as amalgams of general and specific variance is practical for diagnostic purposes (Hopwood, 2018).  To accommodate this complexity, maladaptive traits models have been intentionally constructed to depart from a simple structure to allow interstitial symptoms (Krueger & Markon, 2014). For the purposes of articulating and validating the conceptual model, however, it is necessary to clarify the nature of what is shared among traits and what is unique about them.
     The majority of research evaluating the validity of maladaptive trait models has not statistically separated these sources of variance, so the nomological network of general and specific trait features are not well-defined.  Research looking at these components independently, using different analytic approaches, have demonstrated that general and specific factors correlate differentially with external criteria (Ringwald et al., 2019; Williams, Scalco, & Simms, 2018) and have distinct developmental trajectories (Hopwood et al., 2011; Wright et al., 2015; 2016).  Other studies have shown specific variance in maladaptive traits provide unique information about outcomes measures, but without examining the complementary shared variance removed from these analyses (i.e., general personality pathology; Creswell et al., 2016; Few et al., 2013; Fowler et al., 2017).  Overall, this work supports the match between theoretical and empirical models, and has helped conceptualize the structure of personality pathology.  
     However, studies of general and specific maladaptive trait features have primarily examined cross-sectional associations.  Cross-sectional methods are not well suited to measure the most clinically definitive aspects of personality pathology: the moment-to-moment patterns of perceiving and responding to situations, particularly interpersonal situations (Sullivan, 1953; Pincus, Hopwood, & Wright, 2018).  Ambulatory assessment (AA), which entails intensive, repeated assessment of an individual over days or weeks, has been used to closely track these dynamics in near real time and with greater ecological validity compared to cross-sectional measures (Shiffman, Stone, & Hufford, 2008; Trull & Ebner-Priemer, 2013).  An intellectual advance enabled by AA has been measurement of temporal variability in affect, behavior, and cognitions.  Variability over time is a pattern consistent with processes of dysregulation that makeup the foundation of clinical conceptualizations of personality pathology (Trull et al., 2008). Most AA research on variability in personality pathology has focused on DSM-defined borderline personality disorder given the criterion for the diagnosis (e.g., affect lability, impulsive behavior; APA, 2013).  As expected clinically, it has been demonstrated that borderline personality disorder symptoms are associated with elevated variability in affect (Ebner-Priemer, 2007; Hepp et al., 2018; Jahng et al., 2011; Mniemne et al., 2018; Santangelo, Bohus & Ebner-Priemer, 2014; Trull et al., 2008), interpersonal behaviors (Russell et al., 2007), and self-esteem (Santangelo, 2017; Zeigler-Hill & Abraham, 2006).
     Despite the value of this research for tethering nomothetic constructs to clinically relevant processes, it has almost exclusively been in relation to categorical models.  As research and clinical practice transitions to using empirically-based models, it is an open question whether and how variability fits into a dimensional trait framework.  Only three studies have used AA in the context of maladaptive traits.  In an undergraduate sample, it was found that maladaptive traits, adjusting for their shared variance, associate differentially with increased average daily interpersonal and self functioning (Roche, 2018).  Two studies have examined day-to-day variability in personality pathology symptoms and found contradictory results.   In a clinical sample, maladaptive traits were uniquely associated with more variability in daily personality disorder symptomology (Wright & Simms, 2016), while in another study using an undergraduate sample, traits were associated with less variability in daily personality functioning (Roche, Jacobson, & Pincus, 2016).  Both of these studies, like Roche (2018), found all traits were associated with more overall dysfunction and distress from day-to-day.  This work is a critical step towards linking maladaptive traits with pathological processes, but the daily sampling schedule is not optimal for capturing many key manifestations of personality pathology that occur at the scale of interactions within a day.
     For instance, consider an individual who tends to view others in an extreme, all-or-nothing manner.  During one interaction with her romantic partner, she is intensely affectionate and subservient. Later in the day, she perceives rejection in her partners’ benign side remark and angrily lashes out at him.  Or consider another individual with self-esteem contingent others’ views of him such that he fluctuates between feeling grandiose and defensively hostile depending on the perceived admiration of others around him at any given moment.  In clinical theories, these dynamics are explained in terms of insecure attachments (Bateman & Fonagy, 2004), cognitive distortions (Beck, Davis, & Freeman, 2014), maladaptive schemas (Young, 1994), or unintegrated object representations (Clarkin, Yeomans, & Kernberg, 1999), and are central to a conceptual, mechanistic model of personality pathology.
     Our previous work is the first to our knowledge to investigate momentary dynamics in relation to maladaptive traits (OSF: https://osf.io/bnsug/).  In a pre-registered replication using two adult samples, we examined associations between maladaptive traits and AA-derived estimates of average positive and negative affect, interpersonal behavior, and perception of others’ behavior across interactions, as well as variability in each of these outcomes.  Interpersonal behavior of self and others was operationalized by dimensions of affiliation (i.e., warm to cold) and dominance (i.e., dominant to submissive). In addition to zero-order associations, we also looked at associations with shared and unique trait variance to distinguish general and specific interpersonal patterns.  We found that general personality pathology (i.e. shared variance between maladaptive traits) and trait style (i.e., trait variance adjusted for covariance with other traits) had theoretically-consistent associations with interpersonal variables.  General personality pathology was characterized by having more distressing and less positive, affiliative interactions overall, as well as more variability in dominant behavior, perceived dominance, and negative affect.  Specific trait styles were associated differentially to average momentary affects and behaviors, but less so to variability.  Taken together, this study showed the structural independence of general and specific features and reinforced their validity for predicting functioning in everyday life.
     The current study will replicate and extend our previous work in two, important ways.  We will use two samples representing a range of personality functioning needed to properly test a dimensional trait model, but are also enriched with personality pathology to promote generalizability to clinical populations (Stanton et al., 2020).  In addition to sample composition, this study will build on our previous study by measuring traits with two different instruments (i.e., Personality Inventory for DSM-5 [PID-5; Krueger et al., 2012], Computerized Adaptive Test of Personality Disorder Static Form [CAT-PD-SF; Simms et al., 2011]) to provide convergent validity between methods.
     To establish an overall clinical picture of each trait, and to provide a basis of comparison for multivariate models, we will examine zero-order associations between traits and each of the momentary variables.  Then, to clarify which features reflect general personality pathology and which are indicative of specific style, we will look at associations with all trait’s shared and unique variance.  By connecting momentary interpersonal patterns with total, shared, and unique variance in maladaptive traits we will provide several vantage points to evaluate a general and specific model of personality pathology.

registration_responses.q5: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.
q6: No blinding is involved in this study.
registration_responses.q10: Registration prior to analysis of the data
registration_responses.q11:
The data for S1 (described below) were collected between March 2016 and December 2018.  Aidan Wright (A.W.) was responsible for the study design and supervised the data collection, and Whitney Ringwald (W.R.) was involved with data collection.  However, the data were cleaned and managed by Brinkley Sharpe, the laboratory manager for the Personality Processes and Outcomes Laboratory, who has served as an honest broker and not shared any relevant study details regarding the data used in these proposed analyses prior to this pre-registration.
S2 is a subsample of a longitudinal study with ongoing data collection.  The parent study began data collection in 1990.  Data collection for the sample used in this study began in 2018 and is ongoing.  A.W. was involved in aspects of the study design.  W.R. has not accessed the data prior to this pre-registration.  There have been a number of studies published using prior waves of data from this sample, but none have examined the data or similar models of interest to this study (i.e., maladaptive traits in relation to momentary interpersonal behavior and affect).
registration_responses.q13:
Consistent with a dimensional model, all participants regardless of diagnostic status or level of pathology will be considered in our analyses.  This will ensure adequate representation of varying levels of personality pathology.
To increase the reliability of our AA measurements, we will exclude participants from analysis that report fewer than ten interactions over the course of the AA protocol.  For S1, each separate event including an interaction will be counted (i.e., multiple interactions per survey are possible).  As a result, the final sample size for S1 is 297 and 182 for S2.
registration_responses.q14:
For S1, sample size was determined primarily by the desire to achieve stable estimates of effects rather than power to detect any specific effect size in the population, as well as the ability to detect small effects that are consistent with the average effect in the published personality and social psychological literature.  Recent work showing that correlation estimates of this size begin to stabilize when sample sizes approach N = 250 (Schönbrodt & Perugini, 2013).  Therefore, a minimum sample size of 250 was selected for the most conservative modeling situations of interest, which was establishing between-person associations.  To adjust for expected exclusion due to low participation rates in ~10% of participants, the target sample size was N > 300.
For S2, power calculations were based on goals of the parent study to detect the cross-level interaction of group as a moderator of within-person associations between momentary variables.  Informed by comparable AA studies, it was determined that an average of 52 participants per group (i.e., BPD non-attempters, attempters, high-lethality attempters, and controls) would result in a power of >.99 to detect small, between-group effects.
registration_responses.q20: As noted above, within-person assessed variables will be decomposed into within and between-person variance components. This is akin to person-mean centering the within-person variables and including their averages at the between-person level.
registration_responses.q21: Inferences will be based on point estimates drawn from their posterior distribution and associated 95% credibility intervals.  We will consider coefficients in which the credibility interval does not include zero to be significantly different from the null hypothesis.
registration_responses.q22: As previously noted, we will exclude participants from analysis that report fewer than 10 interactions over the course of the AA protocol to increase the reliability of our AA indices.
registration_responses.q23: Missing data will be assumed to be missing at random, so all available information will be used to estimate model parameters.  It is assumed that missingness is a function of variables included in the model.
registration_responses.q24: As noted in the hypotheses section, in the zero-order models associations between traits and average dominant behavior, perceived dominance, and variability in affiliative behavior, perceived affiliation, positive and negative affect will be exploratory.  In the specific trait variance models, associations between traits and average dominant behavior, perceived dominance, and variability in all criterion variables will be exploratory.  In the latent variable models, associations with average dominant behavior and perceived dominance, and associations with variability in affiliative behavior, perceived affiliation, and perceived dominance will be exploratory.

registration_responses.q12.question:
The data that will be used were not collected for the purpose of this specific study but are derived from two broader studies.  Thus, the sampling approach and some of the measures used are not relevant to the current analysis so are not described in great detail here. 

Sample 1 (S1)
     311 community members were recruited through posted flyers for a study of personality, daily stress, and social interactions.  For inclusion, participants had to be between the ages of 18 and 40 and were not currently receiving treatment for psychosis or a psychotic disorder.
Preliminary screening was used to recruit a gender-balanced sample and to ensure adequate representation of a range of personality pathology and interpersonal problems.  The sample was also selected to balance individuals who had received recent mental health treatment within the past year with those who had not.  Individuals were pre-screened using items from the Inventory of Interpersonal Problems (Morse & Pilkonis, 2007) and were recruited in an approximately 1-1-1 representation of low, moderate, and high levels of interpersonal difficulties within gender, treatment status, and the overall sample.  See Figure 1 for a graphical representation of this recruitment strategy.
     Participation in this study involved completing a battery of baseline assessments in one laboratory session followed by an AA protocol.  All participants received $50 for the baseline session.  Those who answered 90% or greater of the surveys during the AA protocol earned an additional $110 (14-day ambulatory assessment) or $160 (21-day ambulatory assessment).  This amount was prorated by week for those who completed less than 90% of the surveys overall, with surveys completed in later weeks of the study valued higher in the prorated compensation model.  Final payment was contingent upon return of the Fitbit Blaze (and, if applicable, the laboratory-owned smartphone). Additionally, for each 100 participants, a drawing was conducted for an iPad Mini.  Chances of winning increased with the number of surveys answered. 
     During the baseline portion of the study, participants completed a clinical interview and a battery of self-report measures.  Only self-report measures from the baseline assessment will be used for this study.  Following the assessment battery, participants were provided instruction from a research assistant regarding the AA procedures and the required smartphone applications were installed on their phone. For this study, only data collected through the MetricWire application will be used.  Most participants used their own Android or iOS smartphone for completing the AA surveys, however a limited number of laboratory-owned Android smartphones were available for individuals without compatible devices.
AAs typically began the day after the baseline assessment.  The length of assessment period was initially set at 21 days but was later shortened to 14 days.  Surveys were administered through the MetricWire smartphone application.  The AA protocol included surveys at the beginning and end of day as well as random prompt surveys.  A subset of participants received experimental micro surveys, and some participants had an application installed on their smartphones that collected sensor data.  For this study, only data from the random prompts will be used, so the other components of the protocol will not be described further.
Randomly-initiated survey prompts were received through push notifications sent by the MetricWire application.  Six surveys were delivered per day within an approximately 12-hour time window corresponding to the participants’ waking hours.  Blocked random intervals were set so that a minimum of 90 minutes passed between surveys and participants were given 20 minutes to respond to each one.  Each participant completed an average of 68.6 (SD = 20.92) of these surveys.
     At each random prompt, participants were asked whether or not three types of significant events had occurred since the previous survey: stressful, unpleasant, and pleasant.  For each event indicated, participants answered a series of questions including whether any interpersonal interaction was involved.  Thus, 0-3 events could be reported on during each survey.  If any type of event did not occur, the survey ended.  In this study, we will only use responses to surveys including an interaction.  Each event reported per survey will be considered a separate interaction.  
     Interactions were defined as real-time, direct conversations between the participant and one or more other individuals that last for at least five minutes.  These could include in-person, voice, video, and text-based conversations.  For each interaction, participants reported on their own affects and behaviors, and the behaviors of the person they interacted with.  If part of a group interaction, participants were instructed to report on how others behaved on average.  

Sample 2 (S2)
     This sample consists of a case-control subsample of participants drawn from a longitudinal study examining suicidal behavior in relation to borderline personality disorder (BPD).  Participants for the study were recruited from inpatient and outpatient clinics as well as from the surrounding community by advertisement.  For inclusion, participants had to be between the ages of 18 and 45.  Exclusion criteria included lifetime diagnosis of any psychotic or bipolar disorder, clinical evidence of organic brain disease, physical disorders or treatments with known psychiatric consequence (e.g., lupus, steroids), or an IQ < 70 confirmed by assessment in the study.
     The subsample used for the current study (N = 197) participated in an AA protocol, and were selected to represent the four groups identified in the overall sample (described below).  The majority of participants in the subsample meet diagnostic criteria for BPD.  The diagnosis of BPD was determined by standardized semi-structured diagnostic interviews (International Personality Disorders Examination [IPDE; Loranger, 1994] and the Diagnostic Interview for Borderlines-revised [Zanarini et al., 1989]) conducted by masters-level research clinicians.  Diagnoses were confirmed in a consensus conference by raters and two research psychiatrists using all available data, including medical records where available.  All clinical interviews were completed during a baseline assessment.  
     Each participant diagnosed with BPD was further stratified into three groups based on the lethality of reported suicide attempts.  Attempters were defined by a score > 1 (n = 107) on the Beck Lethality Scale, high-lethality attempters by a score >3 (n = 52), and the remaining were non-attempters (n = 67). The control group (n = 75) were required to have no lifetime Axis I or II diagnoses determined on the IPDE or Structured Clinical Interview for DSM-IV, respectively.  
Self-reported maladaptive traits were added to the protocol in 2017.  Thus, for some participants in the sub-sample used in this study, traits were assessed at baseline.  For others who had been participating in the study longer, maladaptive traits were assessed at a follow-up visit.
     All participants in the subsample completed a 21-day AA protocol using a smartphone provided by the study.  The protocol included beginning and end of day assessments, random surveys, and micro surveys.  Only data from the random surveys will be used for this study.  Like S2, six random prompt surveys were delivered each day by push notifications from the MetricWire application.  In each of these surveys, participants indicated whether or not an interaction lasting at least ten minutes had occurred.  When an interaction was reported, participants rated their own affects and behaviors, and the behaviors of the person they interacted with.
registration_responses.q17.question:
Maladaptive traits
     In S1, the Computerized Adaptive Test of Personality Disorder – Static Form (CAT-PD-SF; Simms, 2013) was used to assess maladaptive traits.  The CAT-PD-SF is a self-report measure consisting of 216 items derived from the larger CAT-PD item pool (Simms et al., 2011).  Items are rated on a 5-point Likert scale (0 – Very Untrue of Me; 1 – Moderately Untrue of Me; 2 – Neither True nor Untrue of Me; 3 – Moderately True of Me; 4 – Very True of Me).  The CAT-PD-SF can be used to calculate 33 maladaptive traits: Affective Lability, Anger, Anhedonia, Anxiousness, Callousness, Cognitive Problems, Depressiveness, Domineering, Emotional Detachment, Exhibitionism, Fantasy Proneness, Grandiosity, Health Anxiety, Hostile Aggression, Irresponsibility, Manipulativeness, Mistrust, Non-Perseverance, Non-Planfulness, Norm Violation, Peculiarity, Perfectionism, Relationship Insecurity, Rigidity, Risk Taking, Romantic Disinterest, Rudeness, Self-Harm, Social Withdrawal, Submissiveness, Unusual Beliefs, Unusual Experiences, Workaholism.   
     In S2, maladaptive traits were assessed using The Personality Inventory for the DSM-5 provided by the American Psychiatric Association (Krueger et al., 2012).  It is comprised of 220 items rated on a four-point Likert scale (0—Very False/ Often False; 1 – Sometimes/ Somewhat False; 2—Sometimes/ Somewhat True; 3—Very True or Often True).  Items are used to generate dimensional scores for 25 narrow trait facets. Corresponding facets (3 per trait) can then be averaged to assess broader trait domains of Negative Affect, Detachment, Antagonism, Disinhibition, and Psychoticism (see Table 1).

Momentary affect
     In both samples, momentary affect was measured using emotion adjectives derived from the Positive and Negative Affect Schedule (Watson, Clark & Tellegen, 1988).  In the S1 AA protocol, participants rated their affect during stressful, unpleasant, and pleasant events involving interpersonal interactions (e.g., “How ADJECTIVE did you feel during this [stressful] event?”).  The adjectives Confident and Happy were used for positive affect (PA) and Angry, Nervous, and Sad were used for negative affect (NA).  Affect was indicated on a slider scale from 0 (Not at All) to 100 (Extremely) for each adjective.
     In S2 participants, participants rated their affect during interactions (i.e., “How ADJECTIVE did you feel during this interaction?”).  The adjectives Happy, Excited, and Content were used to measured PA, and NA was measured using the adjectives Angry, Nervous, Sad, and Irritated.  In this sample, affect was rated on a 5-point Likert scale (1 – Very Slightly or Not at all, 2 – A Little; 3 – Moderately; 4 – Quite a Bit; 5 – A great deal).

Momentary interpersonal behavior/ perception of others’ behavior
     Interpersonal behavior was measured identically in both samples.  Participants were prompted to “Please rate how the OTHER PERSON BEHAVED toward you during the interaction” and “Please rate YOUR BEHAVIOR toward the other person during the interaction.”  For both self and other, Dominance (“Accommodating/ Submissive/ Timid” to “Assertive/ Dominant/ Controlling”) and Affiliation (“Cold/ Distant/Hostile” to “Warm/ Friendly/ Caring”) were rated on 101-point slider scales (-50 to +50).

Covariates
     Age and gender of participants will be included as covariates at the between-person level in all analyses.
     Day of week and number of hours in study will be included as covariates at the within-person level in all analyses.  Day of week is dummy coded such that 1=weekend (Saturday, Sunday) and 0=weekday.  Day of study is centered at the average mid-point of the respective study.
registration_responses.q18.question:
Maladaptive traits
     In the PID-5, trait facet scales are averaged to produce the five trait domain scores.  The CAT-PD-SF, on the other hand, was designed to measure 33 narrow traits rather than the five broader domains of interest to this study.  To calculate trait domain-level scores, and to remain consistent across samples, CAT-PD-SF scales that are conceptually comparable to PID-5 facet scales will used to assess the five maladaptive traits.  
     For most PID-5 facets there was a clear corollary in the CAT-PD-SF.  The only exception is for calculating Antagonism, there is not a distinct Deceitfulness scale in the CAT-PD-SF. We will calculate Antagonism with the CAT-PD-SF two ways: 1. Using only the two scales that directly relate to the PID-5 scales (Manipulativeness and Grandiosity) and 2. Using Exhibitionism along with the other two Antagonism scales. 
     The corresponding scales used to calculate each trait are shown in Table 1.  For the CAT-PD-SF, there are six items per trait scale and for the PID-5 there are eight items per facet scale.  Scales are calculated by taking the average of the corresponding items in both instruments.  Then, the three corresponding traits (for the CAT-PD-SF) or facets (PID-5), shown in Table 1, are averaged to produce a score for each of the five maladaptive traits we will use as predictors in our analyses. 

Momentary affect
     Variables from the AA assessments will be indexed using multi-level structural equation modeling (MSEM) which will be mentioned here and described in greater detail in the analysis plan.
     Prior to MSEM, in both samples, adjectives corresponding to PA/NA for each survey will be averaged to produce a single, occasion-level (i.e., interaction) score for each.  Each individual’s average affect across interactions will be estimated using random intercepts for PA/NA.     Variability in affect across interactions will be estimated as the residual, within-person variance for PA/NA.

Momentary interpersonal behavior/perception of others’ behaviors
     Like affect, in both samples, average affiliative and dominant behavior of self and other across interactions will be estimated using random intercepts and within-person residual variance will be used to estimate variability in interpersonal behavior and perception.
registration_responses.q19.question:
Main Analyses

All MSEM models will be conducted in Mplus Version 8.4 (2019).  Syntax for models are provided on the OSF page for this study.

     Using this method, total variance in the observed measures of interpersonal behavior, perception, and affect was decomposed into within- and between-person latent variables.  In MSEM, both outcomes and predictors have both within- and between-person variance.  In addition, within-person (i.e., Level 1) residuals were modeled as heterogenous across individuals (i.e., Level 2 units).  This enables the residual coefficients to vary between individuals (i.e., individual differences in level of variability) and become outcomes at the between-person level (i.e., to examine trait predictors of variability).  Residuals can be interpreted as the individual’s variability around their own mean over time and individual differences in the random intercept reflect person-specific averages.  

     First, we will examine associations with total trait variance and each of the outcome variables in a series of zero-order models.  One momentary variable at a time will be regressed on each trait entered separately as a between-person predictor.  To evaluate unique associations, we will regress each momentary variable on all traits simultaneously at the between-person level.  Finally, we will estimate a latent variable from the shared variance among all traits at the between-person level.  Each momentary variable will then be regressed on this latent variable, reflecting general personality pathology.

     Bayesian estimation will be used because it allows modeling of heterogeneity in residual variances of outcome variables at the within-person level.  No prior information about parameter values will be specified (i.e., we used non-informative/diffuse priors that are the default in Mplus).

     To account for potential effects of time trends on behavior and affect, which could affect individual differences in variance, the effect of outcome variables (i.e., interpersonal behavior and affect) regressed on day of week and study day will be included at the within-person level. These effects will be estimated as random. By detrending the data in this way, the residual variances can be more readily interpreted as “true” variability rather than normative shifts in behavior and affect such as a spike in positive emotions over the weekend.  Due to concerns about the dependency of variable means and variability (Baird et al., 2006), we will adjust for their association by regressing within-person residual variance of the outcome variables on the person-specific mean of the same outcome variable. 

Replication Evaluation
To evaluate the extent to which effects replicated across samples, we will interpret overlapping 95% credibility intervals.
