name.value: Religious Cognition and Dehumanization in Israel: We test how religious cognition influences how much Israeli Jews humanize religious ingroup and outgroup members by asking participants to rate their religious ingroup and a number of outgroups on a measure of blatant dehumanization once from their own perspective and once answering how God would want them to.

other.value:
We are interested in exploring whether the hypothesized decrease in dehumanization from self to God is larger for outgroup targets than for participants’ ingroup. This would manifest as a decrease in relative dehumanization, which would be evidenced by a significant interaction between perspective and the contrast comparing participants’ ingroup to their outgroups. We are also interested in seeing whether any decrease in relative dehumanization between participants’ ingroup and target outgroups is moderated by the target outgroup. We will test this using dummy coded models with participants’ ingroup as a reference group. We note that if there is a large effect of perspective on participants’ rating of their ingroup, we are unlikely to observe a decrease in relative dehumanization.

We are also interested in exploring whether Israeli Jews dehumanize outgroup members more along religious or citizenship lines. We include outgroups that vary both in terms of religious identification (Christian & Muslim) as well as in terms of whether they share a superordinate Israeli identity or are residents of the West Bank or Gaza. Similarly, we will explore whether any effect of thinking from God’s perspective differentially applies across these categories to better understand potential boundary conditions of effects. Orthogonal contrasts will be used to probe these questions.

We will test whether effects differ if participants are first presented with the self condition or first presented with the God condition. We anticipate that effects will hold across both; however, we believe it is possible that the effect of perspective will be stronger when participants first complete the self condition and then the God condition. This is because it is possible that there may be a carry-over effect from the God condition (i.e., once God is salient, it may be harder to return to baseline). We will test this in a secondary analysis by including order as a moderator. Specifically, we will reconduct the primary model with order and all two- and three-way interactions included in the model.

We recognize that Israeli participants may be familiar with psychological studies that assess dehumanization. This, we will ask participants if they are familiar with the measure that we administer in this study. We will explore familiarity as a covariate and moderator.

sample.value:
We aim to sample 300 religious Israeli Jews. 

Using data from a prior study (conducted in the US), we conducted a power analysis using the package SimR (Green & MacLeod, 2016). This power analysis indicated that a sample of 200 would provide >99% power to detect a main effect of perspective (increase in humanization of 3.5 points on a 100 point scale) and a > 90% power to detect a significant interaction between perspective and the key contrast of interest comparing ingroup ratings to outgroup ratings (estimating that the increase in outgroup ratings is 1 point greater than that for ingroup ratings). Because we are conducting this study in a new cultural context, and to be conservative, we will sample 300 participants.

analyses.value:
Multilevel models will be conducted to analyze results. We will compute a single outcome score corresponding to how human-like (or animal like) participants see each target group as being. We will regress this score on (1) target group (as a set of orthogonal contrasts), (2) perspective (self vs God), and their interaction. 

In primary models, target group will be entered as a set of orthogonal contrasts, allowing us to (1) estimate a main effect of perspective collapsed across the ingroup and outgroup conditions, (2) test for differences at baseline in how human-like or animal-like participants see their ingroup as being compared to their outgroups, and (3) to test for an interaction between perspective and a contrast comparing participants’ ingroup to their outgroups. This interaction allows a parsimonious test of whether any change in dehumanization from the self to God conditions is dependent on whether participants are rating their ingroup or outgroups. We will also test simple effects of perspective for each target group. 

An additional model will test for robustness by including age, gender, and religiosity as covariates. Religiosity will be measured with the 10-item Religious Commitment Inventory (Worthington et al., 2003).

outliers.value: We will exclude from this sample participants who fail a manipulation check. In this manipulation check, participants will be asked whose perspective they were asked to take into consideration. Options are: their parents, god, the average person, and Benjamin Netanyahu. We will also exclude any participants who complete this study in less than 1/3rd the median completion time.

dependent.value:
We will measure dehumanization using a modified version of Kteily and colleagues' ascent scale (Kteily, Bruneau, Waytz, & Cotterill, 2015). This scale is modified for use with religious samples by removing anchor levels between the ape and human (to prevent conflict with beliefs about evolution).
In each condition (self and God), participants will rate their ingroup (Israeli Jews) and five relevant outgroups (Muslim Arab Israelis, Christian Arab Israelis, Muslim Palestinians living in the West Bank, Muslim Palestinians living in Gaza, Christian Palestinians).

conditions.value: This study employs a 2 (self vs. God) x 6 (target group) fully within person design. We will also randomly assign participants to one between-subjects condition (order), with the order of the self and God conditions counterbalanced.

hypothesis.value:
We seek to test how religious cognition influences how much Israeli Jews humanize (or dehumanize) religious ingroup and outgroup members. Specifically, we will ask participants to rate their religious ingroup and a number of outgroups on a measure of blatant dehumanization. Participants will complete this task twice: one time from their own perspective, and one time answering how God would want them to.

Hypothesis 1: Participants will rate outgroup members as more human-like (and less animal-like) when considering God’s preferences than when answering from their own perspective.

Hypothesis 2: Participants will rate ingroup members as more human-like (and less animal-like) when considering God’s preferences than when answering from their own perspective. We note, however, that if participants exhibit a ceiling effect for their ingroup in the self-condition (i.e., view their ingroup as uniformly human), we do not anticipate a discrepancy between ingroup ratings in the self and God conditions. 

Note: We note that the above hypotheses correspond to within-person change between the self and God conditions. That is, we do not make hypotheses about between-subject comparisons between the self and God conditions at time 1 or time 2. This is because our primary question of interests concerns the difference that participants see between their own and God’s beliefs.

attributes.title: Internalized Misogyny and Sexist Events
attributes.description: Study 1 will investigate how group identification and gendered system justification predict internalized misogyny. Study 2 aims to explore the extent to which internalized misogyny predicts attributions of discrimination to a sexist event, as well as how uncertainty moderates this relationship.
attributes.registration_supplement: Pre-Registration in Social Psychology (van 't Veer & Giner-Sorolla, 2016): Pre-Registration

question10b.value:
Approximately 50% of participants will be randomly assigned to a high-uncertainty manipulation, where they will be asked to type out three aspects of their life that makes them feel uncertain, or a low-uncertainty manipulation, where they will write about what makes them feel certain. This will be followed by items related to group identity, a gendered system justification scale and an internalized misogyny scale, followed by some basic demographic questions. After survey completion, they will be redirected to the Prolific Academic page, where they can receive compensation for participating in the survey a few days after completion. 
Study 2 will also include the uncertainty manipulation used in Study 1. In addition, it will randomly assign participants to a short vignette describing a high/low sexism event after the uncertainty prime. These manipulations will be followed by scales on attributions to discrimination, attributions to applicant’s qualifications, internalized misogyny, and demographic questions.

This will be a blinded study, because participants will not be aware of which condition they have been assigned to.

question4b.value:
For both Study 1 and Study 2, participants will be pre-screened using Prolific Academic’s pre-screening feature, only to include those who report their sex as "woman", as stated on the Prolific Academic webpage, and the United States as their country of residence. All pre-screening data is self-reported. Prolific Academic panel participants report their demographic information before gaining access to surveys. Using pre-screened criteria may help avoid the problem of lying about inclusion criteria to gain access to the survey.
We will also include a gender-identity demographic variable in our survey to ensure Prolific Academic’s pre-screening process works as it should. Participants who do not self-report themselves as a woman will be removed from our analysis.

question5b.value: Data will be collected via Prolific Academic. Prolific Academic is a crowdsourcing website that focuses on academic research (https://www.prolific.co/). Prolific Academic’s panel members who met the inclusion criteria will be shown the survey task when logged into their profile. The link in Prolific Academic will redirect them to a Qualtrics survey. Participants will be provided information about the study, including the study’s purpose, risks and benefits of participation, researcher contact information, and will be asked if they agree to participate in the study. If they agree, participants will be asked to continue and complete the 15-minute survey.

question6b.value:
A target number of 276 participants will be recruited for Study 1. A target number of 106 participants will be recruited for Study 2
The sample size for study 1 is based on a power analysis for linear regression which shows that to obtain a power level of 0.90 and a significance level of 0.05, a sample size of 230 is the minimum required size for recruitment per study.  We will exclude participants from our analysis who fail their attention checks, are univariate or multivariate normality outliers or have observed non-response. We assume that 20% of participants will be excluded for these reasons, but will compensate all participants who complete the survey. We aim to oversample by 46 participants for a total of 276 participants.
The sample size for study 2 is based on a power analysis for linear regression which shows that to obtain a power level of 0.90 and a significance level of 0.05, a sample size of 133 is the minimum required size for recruitment per study.  We will exclude participants from our analysis who fail their attention checks, are univariate or multivariate normality outliers or have observed non-response. We assume that 20% of participants will be excluded for these reasons. s, but will compensate all participants who complete the survey. We aim to oversample by 27 participants for a total of 160 participants.

question7b.value:
A target number of 276 participants will be recruited for Study 1. A target number of 106 participants will be recruited for Study 2. 

If more than 20% do not pass attention checks, additional participants may be recruited.

question8b.value:
Participants who do not self-report themselves as a “woman” will be removed from our analysis.

We will exclude participants who fail their attention checks, are univariate or multivariate normality outliers or have observed non-response. 

We will also employ listwise deletion of participant data that is incomplete or has more than one failed attention check. We will remove participants who exhibit univariate non-normality by running descriptive statistics analyses on the results using the descriptives command and removing participants who exhibit skew and kurtosis exceeding ± 3. We also intend to remove data points that exceed Mahalanobis’ distance, which will address multivariate outliers. We will do this by creating a distribution of Mahalanobis’ distances for all data points, and eliminate outliers that lie above or below 3 standard deviations from the Mahalanobis distance mean. Regarding the assumption of multicollinearity, we will test Variance Inflation Factor (VIF) values and remove data points with a VIF exceeding 4. We will generate a plot of standardized residuals versus predicted values to show whether points are equally distributed across all values of the independent variables and remove points that are not equally distributed.

question7c.value: We will employ listwise deletion of participants that are missing more than 5% of their data.

question1a.value:
Hypothesis 1A: Gender-specific system justification will be positively associated with internalized misogyny.
Hypothesis 1B: Group identification will be negatively associated with internalized misogyny.
Hypothesis 1C: Uncertainty will increase the intensity of the relationship between gender-specific system justification and internalized misogyny.
Hypothesis 1D: Uncertainty will increase the intensity of the relationship between group identification and internalized misogyny.

Study 2:

Hypothesis 2A: Internalized misogyny will be negatively associated with attributions to discrimination.
Hypothesis 2B: Uncertainty will moderate the relationship between internalized misogyny and attributions to discrimination.

question1c.value:
Study 1:

registration_responses.description-methods.procedure.question10:
Approximately 50% of participants will be randomly assigned to a high-uncertainty manipulation, where they will be asked to type out three aspects of their life that makes them feel uncertain, or a low-uncertainty manipulation, where they will write about what makes them feel certain. This will be followed by items related to group identity, a gendered system justification scale and an internalized misogyny scale, followed by some basic demographic questions. After survey completion, they will be redirected to the Prolific Academic page, where they can receive compensation for participating in the survey a few days after completion. 
Study 2 will also include the uncertainty manipulation used in Study 1. In addition, it will randomly assign participants to a short vignette describing a high/low sexism event after the uncertainty prime. These manipulations will be followed by scales on attributions to discrimination, attributions to applicant’s qualifications, internalized misogyny, and demographic questions.

This will be a blinded study, because participants will not be aware of which condition they have been assigned to.

registration_responses.description-methods.planned-sample.quest:
For both Study 1 and Study 2, participants will be pre-screened using Prolific Academic’s pre-screening feature, only to include those who report their sex as "woman", as stated on the Prolific Academic webpage, and the United States as their country of residence. All pre-screening data is self-reported. Prolific Academic panel participants report their demographic information before gaining access to surveys. Using pre-screened criteria may help avoid the problem of lying about inclusion criteria to gain access to the survey.
We will also include a gender-identity demographic variable in our survey to ensure Prolific Academic’s pre-screening process works as it should. Participants who do not self-report themselves as a woman will be removed from our analysis.

Data will be collected via Prolific Academic. Prolific Academic is a crowdsourcing website that focuses on academic research (https://www.prolific.co/). Prolific Academic’s panel members who met the inclusion criteria will be shown the survey task when logged into their profile. The link in Prolific Academic will redirect them to a Qualtrics survey. Participants will be provided information about the study, including the study’s purpose, risks and benefits of participation, researcher contact information, and will be asked if they agree to participate in the study. If they agree, participants will be asked to continue and complete the 15-minute survey.

A target number of 276 participants will be recruited for Study 1. A target number of 106 participants will be recruited for Study 2
The sample size for study 1 is based on a power analysis for linear regression which shows that to obtain a power level of 0.90 and a significance level of 0.05, a sample size of 230 is the minimum required size for recruitment per study.  We will exclude participants from our analysis who fail their attention checks, are univariate or multivariate normality outliers or have observed non-response. We assume that 20% of participants will be excluded for these reasons, but will compensate all participants who complete the survey. We aim to oversample by 46 participants for a total of 276 participants.
The sample size for study 2 is based on a power analysis for linear regression which shows that to obtain a power level of 0.90 and a significance level of 0.05, a sample size of 133 is the minimum required size for recruitment per study.  We will exclude participants from our analysis who fail their attention checks, are univariate or multivariate normality outliers or have observed non-response. We assume that 20% of participants will be excluded for these reasons. s, but will compensate all participants who complete the survey. We aim to oversample by 27 participants for a total of 160 participants.

A target number of 276 participants will be recruited for Study 1. A target number of 106 participants will be recruited for Study 2. 

If more than 20% do not pass attention checks, additional participants may be recruited.

registration_responses.description-methods.exclusion-criteria.q:
Participants who do not self-report themselves as a “woman” will be removed from our analysis.

We will exclude participants who fail their attention checks, are univariate or multivariate normality outliers or have observed non-response. 

We will also employ listwise deletion of participant data that is incomplete or has more than one failed attention check. We will remove participants who exhibit univariate non-normality by running descriptive statistics analyses on the results using the descriptives command and removing participants who exhibit skew and kurtosis exceeding ± 3. We also intend to remove data points that exceed Mahalanobis’ distance, which will address multivariate outliers. We will do this by creating a distribution of Mahalanobis’ distances for all data points, and eliminate outliers that lie above or below 3 standard deviations from the Mahalanobis distance mean. Regarding the assumption of multicollinearity, we will test Variance Inflation Factor (VIF) values and remove data points with a VIF exceeding 4. We will generate a plot of standardized residuals versus predicted values to show whether points are equally distributed across all values of the independent variables and remove points that are not equally distributed.

attributes.title: Perceptions of Political Polarization in the U.S.

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

sample.value: At Time 1, we will collect data from 600 individuals (300 Democrats and 300 Republicans) using the Prolific Academic platform.

analyses.value:
==Confirmatory Analyses==
Testing H1
First, we will use two dummy codes (Dynamic and Static) with Control as a reference category. We then conduct a regression model for each DV predicted by:
Dynamic and Static dummy variables
Covariate 1: Corresponding Time 1 DV
Covariate 2: Net partisan affect (feelings thermometer for the own party - the opposite party)
Covariate 3: American identification

If we find coefficients of two dummy codes to be significant, we have full support for H1. If one of the coefficients is significant, we have partial support for H1. If neither of coefficients is significant, we do not have any support for H1. 

Testing H2a and H2b
First, we will use two dummy codes (Dynamic and Control) with Static as a reference category. We then conduct a regression model for each DV predicted by:
Dynamic and Control dummy variables
Covariate 1: Corresponding Time 1 DV
Covariate 2: Net partisan affect (feelings thermometer for the own party - the opposite party)
Covariate 3: American identification

If we find the coefficient for Dynamic to be significant, we have support for H2a (“animation adds above and beyond the depiction of overlap”). If not, we have support for H2b (“simply depicting the overlap is enough”).

==Supplementary analyses==
We will check that we have equal numbers of conditions by conducting a chi-square test
We will also check to see the success of random assignment by conducting one-way ANOVA on DV1 and DV2 at Time 1 as well as checking the breakdown of demographics in each condition. If we find that there are big discrepancies at Time 1, we will interpret any main results with caution appropriately.
We will also test H3 that the effects of experimental conditions are somewhat weaker for those with strong American identification. We conclude support for H3 if we find significant interactions between the first contrast and American identification. We would expect coefficients for interaction terms between dummy codes (with control being the reference group) and American identification to be significant.

DV1: General
How similar do you think Democrats and Republicans are in their political attitudes in general?

The responses to these scores will be averaged to represent the perceptions of political polarization.

conditions.value:
This is a two-part study. At Time 1, we will collect the baseline measures from participants to be used as covariates. Two to four days after Time 1, we will conduct an experimental study in which participants are randomly assigned to one of three conditions on Qualtrics. We plan to get equal numbers of participants in three conditions. If there is no attrition from Time 1 to Time 2, we would expect to have a little less than 200 participants in each condition after specified exclusion criteria.
1: Those in the Control Condition will be asked to think about the distance between views of Democratic and Republican voters on a blank page for 5 seconds.
2: Those in the Dynamic Condition will be asked to watch a 5-second animation in which the opinion distributions converge on the current estimated overlap in partisans’ views.
3: Those in the Static Condition will be asked to look at the static image of the current estimated overlap for 5 seconds.

hypothesis.value:
In this project, we test the malleability of perceptions of political polarization between Democrats and Republicans. In a previous experimental study, we found that people who watched a short animation in which the opinion distributions of Democrats and Republicans converged on the current estimated overlap in partisans’ views were more likely to rate Democrats and Republicans to be similar across a range of issues than those who didn’t watch any animation.

In this replication/extension, we plan to test whether a simple static image showing the overlap between Democrats’ and Republicans' views vs. the converging animation from the initial study would also decrease perceptions of opinion polarization. We predict that (H1) those who see the static image (Static Condition) or who see the dynamic animation (Dynamic Condition) will rate Democrats and Republicans to be more similar than those who simply are asked to imagine the distance between Democrats and Republicans (Control Condition). With regard to the effects of the Static and Dynamic Conditions on perceptions of polarization, we have two competing hypotheses: (H2a) Static > Dynamic > Control and (H2b) Static = Dynamic > Control.

If H2b is supported, we will conclude that any visual representation of overlap is helpful in mitigating perceptions of political polarization. On the other hand, if H2a is supported, we will conclude that animation adds more information above and beyond showing the static image of the current estimated overlap.

q1.value: Evolving Work Behaviours and the Role of the Commute

q2.value: Zakiyya Adam, Lukasz Walasek, Caroline Meyer

q3.value:
As technology takes a more prominent role in individual's lives, working behaviours are changing. This study aims to investigate whether working from home (or elsewhere outside of the office) outside of working hours is correlated to how individual's value their commute to/from work. 

Understanding attitudes towards commuting would enable organisations to make informed decisions when planning future employee provisions. Commuting has traditionally been found to be valued as a buffer between the domains of work and personal life. If this holds true for those working from home outside of office hours, then it might imply that individuals would choose to continue to commute to work despite technological advancements that further enable teleworking.

q4.value:
Primary Analysis
1. Those who have a clearer divide between their work domain and personal life domain (both perceived and objective) will feel more strongly that their commute helps them to separate their personal life and work life

2. Those who have a clearer divide between their work domain and personal life domain (both perceived and objective) will feel more strongly that their commute gives them time to get into the right mindset for home/work

3. Those who have a clearer divide between their work domain and personal life domain (both perceived and objective) will express less desire to teleport to work

4. Those who have a clearer divide between their work domain and personal life domain (both perceived and objective) will express less desire to teleport from work

5. Those who have a clearer divide between their work domain and personal life domain (both perceived and objective) will place greater value on their commute to work

6. Those who have a clearer divide between their work domain and personal life domain (both perceived and objective) will place greater value on their commute from work


Exploratory Analysis
1. The more days that an individual carries out work-related tasks outside of the office and outside of working hours (i.e. the weaker the objective divide), the weaker the perceived divide between their work domain and personal life domain will be.
If the two variables – perceived divide and objective divide – are found to be highly correlated, then the primary analysis will only be carried out using the ratings for perceived divide. This would result in six, rather than twelve, sets of analysis

2. Evaluations of the Value of the Commute will be distinct from ratings on the Satisfaction with Travel Scale (STS).
If the two measures – Value and STS – are found to be highly correlated, then the more established, and validated, STS measure will replace Value in the Primary Analysis (hypotheses 5 and 6)

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: The observational study will be cross-sectional

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
All data will be collected directly from participants. Data collection will be undertaken using an online survey created using Qualtrics. The website Prolific will be used to recruit participants; a small reward of £1.20 (calculated at a rate of £6/hr) will be paid to all participants who complete the survey. 

The online survey will be open to all participants who meet the following criteria: (1) in employment/self-employed, (2) over the age of 18, (3) commuters (at least once a week), (4) English speaking, and (5) living in the UK. Prolific will screen participants to ensure that they meet the criteria and will only offer the survey to those who do. 

There are 30 questions included in the survey and, according to the Qualtrics estimate, it will take approximately 12 minutes to complete. The survey is split into six sections. The first two sections ask a series of questions to establish the individual's attitudes towards commuting. The third section covers employment, both with regards to the individual's attitudes towards their employment and also details on the nature of the employment; questions on the latter include income. The fourth section collects details on the nature of the commute, such as the mode of transport, duration and activities carried out during this time. The fifth section comprises of the seven SWEMWBS mental well-being questions. The final section covers socio-demographic information: sex, age, relationship status, number of children in the household, education and disability.

q13.value:
A convenience sample of 400 individuals who commute by car will be the target. Based on power analysis, a minimum of 183 responses will be required in order to carry out the planned regression analyses.
The survey will also be distributed to 50 individuals who walk to/from work and 50 who commute by train. These responses will not be used for the analyses outlined in this registration and are intended for analysis as part of a separate, qualitative, study.

q14.value: The pwr package in R was used to conduct power analysis. The goal was to obtain .9 power, with numerator degrees of freedom of 18, to detect a medium effect size of .15 at the standard .05 alpha error probability.

question.value:
Primary Analysis

Six dependant variables, corresponding to the six hypotheses, will be tested using separate models:
1. The commute as a means to separate the work domain and personal life domain. Participants will be asked to rate the following statement on a scale from 1 Strongly Disagree to 7 Strongly Agree: “My commute helps me to separate my personal life and professional life”
2. The commute as time to get into the mindset for what follows. Participants will be asked to rate the following statement on a scale from 1 Strongly Disagree to 7 Strongly Agree: “My commute gives me time to get into the right mindset for home/work”
3. The desire to be able to teleport to work, negating the need for the commute. Participants will be asked: “Imagine you could hypothetically teleport to/from work (in other words, click your fingers and magically appear at your workplace). 
On how many of your next 10 commutes would you choose to teleport TO work rather than commute?”
4. The desire to be able to teleport from work, negating the need for the commute. Participants will be asked: “Imagine you could hypothetically teleport to/from work (in other words, click your fingers and magically appear at your workplace). 
On how many of your next 10 commutes would you choose to teleport FROM work rather than commute?”
5. How valuable the individual perceives their commute to work to be to them. Participants will first be instructed: 
“The following questions are about the value you place on your commute.
Think about the time you spend commuting. Aside from getting you to/from work, how beneficial is this time to you? How disadvantageous? What role does your commute play in your day?”
Participants will then be asked to rate the following statement on a scale of 1 Strongly Disagree to 7 Strongly Agree: “I value my commute TO work”
6. How valuable the individual perceives their commute from work to be to them. This question will immediately follow the one described in No. 5 above and the same instructional paragraph applies. Participants will be asked to rate the following statement on a scale of 1 Strongly Disagree to 7 Strongly Agree: “I value my commute FROM work”

The independent variable is the divide that an individual has between their work domain and personal life domain. Data is collected on both the objective divide and the perceived/subjective divide. Both measures will be tested using separate models. The two questions are preceded by the following instructional paragraph: 
“For the following questions...
Think of a typical day on which you commute to/from work. Think about how you spend your time outside of working hours AND outside of the office. For example, in the morning before work and in the evening after work. This does not include staying late at your workplace or going in early.
Whilst thinking about this time, please answer the following questions:”
1. Objective Divide: “How many days a week, on average, do you carry out any work-related activities during this time?”
2. Subjective Divide: “Please indicate the level to which you feel your work and personal life merge based on the amount of effort/time you spend working during this time?”, a scale is provided ranging from 1 Clear Divide between Work and Personal Life and 7 No Divide Between Work and Personal Life. 

6 variables will be included as controls in the models. 
1. Duration of Commute
Participants will be asked: “Please estimate, in minutes, the duration of your typical one-way commute?”
2. Commute Time Dissonance
Calculated by subtracting the actual commute time by the ideal commute time.
Participants will be asked: “Please estimate, in minutes, the duration of your typical one-way commute?”
and “Disregarding the feasibility of whether this is actually achievable (based on practical elements such as distance), what would be the duration of your ideal one-way commute?”
3. Job Satisfaction
Participants will be asked to rate their job satisfaction on a scale from 1 Completely Dissatisfied to 7 Completely Satisfied
4. Income
Participants will be asked: “Please indicate the category in which your total annual income falls, before deductions for Income Tax, National Insurance etc.” Options will be based on the ONS Income Band recommendations for survey questions: (1) Up to £2,599, (2) £2,600 up to £5,199, (3) £5,200 up to £10,399, (4) £10,400 up to £15,599, (5) £15,600 up to  £20,799, (6) £20,800 up to £25,999, (7) £26,000 up to £31,199, (8) £31,200 up to £36,366, (9) £36,400 up to £41,599, (10) £41,600 up to £46,799, (11) £46,800 up to £51,999, (12) £52,000 or more.
5. Sex
Participants will be asked: “What is your sex?” Options: (1) Male, (2) Female, (3)Other, (4) Prefer Not To Say
6. Age
Participants will be asked: “What is your age?” and provided with a text box 



Exploratory Analysis

The first hypothesis utilises the two variables measuring objective and subjective divide between the personal life domain and the professional domain detailed earlier and copied here for ease:
“For the following questions...
Think of a typical day on which you commute to/from work. Think about how you spend your time outside of working hours AND outside of the office. For example, in the morning before work and in the evening after work. This does not include staying late at your workplace or going in early.
Whilst thinking about this time, please answer the following questions:”
1. Objective Divide: “How many days a week, on average, do you carry out any work-related activities during this time?”
2. Subjective Divide: “Please indicate the level to which you feel your work and personal life merge based on the amount of effort/time you spend working during this time?”, a scale is provided ranging from 1 Clear Divide between Work and Personal Life and 7 No Divide Between Work and Personal Life. 

The second hypothesis involves the two measures for evaluating the commute: Value and the STS.
Value of the commute is detailed above as the fifth and sixth dependant variables for the primary analysis.
The STS questions are as follows, they are asked for the commute to work and from work separately, and presented here for the commute to work:
“For each of the following pairs, please select the choice that best describes how you felt overall during your commute TO work over the last four weeks” The following nine statements are then presented to the participant… “I was very tense/relaxed”, “I was very bored/enthusiastic”, “I was very sad/happy”, “I was very tired/energised”, “I was very distressed/content”, “My trips went poorly/smoothly”, “My trips were displeasing/enjoyable”, “I was worried/confident that I wouldn’t/would arrive on time”, and “My trips were the worst/best that I can imagine”

Primary Analysis
Commute Time Dissonance - Commute Time Dissonance will be calculated by subtracting the ideal commute time from the actual commute time. 

Exploratory Analysis
Satisfaction with Travel Scale (STS) - Each of the nine statements will have been assigned a score between -3 and 3. The overall STS score for the individual will be obtained by averaging across all nine items.

Primary Analysis
Multiple regression will be used. The core of the analysis will consist of two sets of six models – for one of the sets the independent variable will be the objective divide between the work domain and the personal life domain, and for the other set it will be the measure for subjective divide; these independent variables are described in Section 17. The dependant variable for each of the models within the sets will be one of the six variables detailed in Section 17, each variable tests one of the hypotheses: (1) separate domains, (2) mindset, (3) teleport to work, (4) teleport from work, (5) value to work, and (6) value from work. The six model controls will be included in each of the models. 

The core models will take the form:
Dependent Variable ~ Independent Variable + Duration + Commute Time Dissonance + Job Satisfaction + Income + Sex + Age



Exploratory Analysis
Multiple regression will be used for both analyses. 

To test the first of the hypotheses, the objective divide against perceived divide, the models will take the form:
Perceived Divide ~ Objective Divide + Duration + Commute Time Dissonance + Job Satisfaction + Income + Sex + Age

To test the second hypothesis, the model will take the following form:
STS ~ Value + Duration + Commute Time Dissonance + Job Satisfaction + Income + Sex + Age

registration_responses.q1: Evolving Work Behaviours and the Role of the Commute
registration_responses.q2: Zakiyya Adam, Lukasz Walasek, Caroline Meyer
registration_responses.q3:
As technology takes a more prominent role in individual's lives, working behaviours are changing. This study aims to investigate whether working from home (or elsewhere outside of the office) outside of working hours is correlated to how individual's value their commute to/from work. 

Understanding attitudes towards commuting would enable organisations to make informed decisions when planning future employee provisions. Commuting has traditionally been found to be valued as a buffer between the domains of work and personal life. If this holds true for those working from home outside of office hours, then it might imply that individuals would choose to continue to commute to work despite technological advancements that further enable teleworking.
registration_responses.q4:
Primary Analysis
1. Those who have a clearer divide between their work domain and personal life domain (both perceived and objective) will feel more strongly that their commute helps them to separate their personal life and work life

2. Those who have a clearer divide between their work domain and personal life domain (both perceived and objective) will feel more strongly that their commute gives them time to get into the right mindset for home/work

3. Those who have a clearer divide between their work domain and personal life domain (both perceived and objective) will express less desire to teleport to work

4. Those who have a clearer divide between their work domain and personal life domain (both perceived and objective) will express less desire to teleport from work

5. Those who have a clearer divide between their work domain and personal life domain (both perceived and objective) will place greater value on their commute to work

6. Those who have a clearer divide between their work domain and personal life domain (both perceived and objective) will place greater value on their commute from work


Exploratory Analysis
1. The more days that an individual carries out work-related tasks outside of the office and outside of working hours (i.e. the weaker the objective divide), the weaker the perceived divide between their work domain and personal life domain will be.
If the two variables – perceived divide and objective divide – are found to be highly correlated, then the primary analysis will only be carried out using the ratings for perceived divide. This would result in six, rather than twelve, sets of analysis

2. Evaluations of the Value of the Commute will be distinct from ratings on the Satisfaction with Travel Scale (STS).
If the two measures – Value and STS – are found to be highly correlated, then the more established, and validated, STS measure will replace Value in the Primary Analysis (hypotheses 5 and 6)

registration_responses.q12.question:
All data will be collected directly from participants. Data collection will be undertaken using an online survey created using Qualtrics. The website Prolific will be used to recruit participants; a small reward of £1.20 (calculated at a rate of £6/hr) will be paid to all participants who complete the survey. 

The online survey will be open to all participants who meet the following criteria: (1) in employment/self-employed, (2) over the age of 18, (3) commuters (at least once a week), (4) English speaking, and (5) living in the UK. Prolific will screen participants to ensure that they meet the criteria and will only offer the survey to those who do. 

There are 30 questions included in the survey and, according to the Qualtrics estimate, it will take approximately 12 minutes to complete. The survey is split into six sections. The first two sections ask a series of questions to establish the individual's attitudes towards commuting. The third section covers employment, both with regards to the individual's attitudes towards their employment and also details on the nature of the employment; questions on the latter include income. The fourth section collects details on the nature of the commute, such as the mode of transport, duration and activities carried out during this time. The fifth section comprises of the seven SWEMWBS mental well-being questions. The final section covers socio-demographic information: sex, age, relationship status, number of children in the household, education and disability.

attributes.title: Neural mechanisms underlying enhanced visual search performance in action video game players

q1.value: Neural mechanism underlying enhanced visual search performance in action video game players.

q2.value: Kait Clark, Lucy Archer, Austin C P Petrie, Alice Stephenson, Kayley Birch-Hurst

q3.value:
Pre-registration prepared by Kayley Birch-Hurst

Individuals who play action video games have demonstrated faster response times on different measures of cognitive ability (e.g. Green & Bavelier, 2003), but many changes across the neurocognitive processing chain could contribute to the ultimate quickening in response. Some evidence suggests that enhanced performance in video gamers is attributed to changes in basic early sensory processes, whereas other work has shown performance benefits involving changes to higher cognitive processes such as shifts in attentional allocation or strategy use (Clark, Fleck & Mitroff, 2011). Some studies have begun to identify neural markers associated with enhanced performance in gamers using the event-related potential (e.g. Clark et al., 2015), but to establish which components of the neurocognitive processing chain facilitates the observed behavioural change additional research is required. In the planned study we aim to identify which components of the neurocognitive processing chain contribute to faster response times in individuals who play action video games relative to non-gamers, using similar methodology as Clark et al. (2015). We plan to test action video game players (VGP’s) and non-video game players (NVGP’s) on a visual search ‘popout’ task whilst recording EEG. We will assess the amplitudes and latencies of several key ERP components: the N1 (early sensory processing) component; the N2pc (attentional orienting to stimulus); the CDA (target processing, discrimination, and manipulation of information in visual short-term memory); and both the stimulus-locked and response locked LRPs (preparation for motor response). 
The aim of the proposed study is to establish which components of the neurocognitive processing chain are accountable for VGP’s outperforming NVGP’s in visuo-attentional task, such as visual search. We will be working with a student population to identify changes in ERP components across the neurocognitive chain in a visual search task. 
References 
Clark, K., Appelbaum, L. G., van den Berg, B., Mitroff, S. R., & Woldorff, M. G. (2015). Improvement in visual search with practice: mapping learning-related changes in neurocognitive stages of processing. Journal of Neuroscience, 35(13), 5351-5359.
Clark, K., Fleck, M. S., & Mitroff, S. R. (2011). Enhanced change detection performance reveals improved strategy use in avid action video game players. Acta psychologica, 136(1), 67-72.
Green, C. S., & Bavelier, D. (2003). Action video game modifies visual selective attention. Nature, 423(6939), 534-537.

q4.value:
The following hypotheses relate to select analyses in which we expect to have appropriate power (see Sample Size Rationale section) to detect our effects. Additional variables will be measured and assessed to provide a complete picture of the mechanisms underlying visual search performance from stimulus to response; however, based on the effect sizes observed in prior work (Clark et al., 2015), we likely do not have the appropriate power to assess such ERP components with the somewhat-limited sample size of an EEG study. Therefore we include the planned analyses for such ERP components in the exploratory analyses section. The following hypotheses are our planned confirmatory hypotheses only.
H1: VGP’s will have quicker response times than NVGP’s.
There is a growing body of research to suggest that playing action video games improves performance on a range of perceptual and cognitive tasks. In general, VGP’s show shorter reaction times than NVGP’s (e.g., Dye, Green & Bavelier, 2009).
H2: There will be no differences in the peak latency of the N2pc component between VGP’s and NVGP’s. 
Faster allocation of attentional resources in VGP’s may underly the enhanced visual attention and visuospatial abilities shown by VGP’s compared to NVGP’s (Bavelier, Achtman, Mani & Focker, 2012a). However, the present study relies upon covert attention, and no significant differences in the speed of covert attention shifts between VGP’s and NVGP’s has been found (Mack, Wiesmann & Ilg, 2016). 
H3: VGPs will demonstrate differences in LRP latencies (specific hypotheses below). 
Despite earlier reports indicating that VGP’s show an increased ability to process information over time (e.g. Green, Pouget & Bavelier, 2010), there is evidence to suggest that playing action video games does not improve the speed of information processing in perceptual tasks (van Ravenzwaaij, Boekel, Fortsmann, Ratcliff & Wagenmakers, 2014). This suggests that the underlying difference may lie in the motor-response initiation and/or the motor response. 
H3a: VGP’s will initiate the motor response earlier than NVGP’s. The onset of the stimulus-locked LRP will be earlier in VGP’s than NVGP’s. 
H3b: VGP’s will initiate the motor response earlier than NVGP’s. The peak latency of the stimulus-locked LRP will be earlier in VGP’s than NVGP’s.
H3c: VGP’s will show more rapid motor execution after motor-response initiation. The onset of the response-locked LRP will be closer in time to the behavioural response in VGP’s compared to NVGP’s. 
References
van Ravenzwaaij, D., Boekel, W., Forstmann, B. U., Ratcliff, R., & Wagenmakers, E. J. (2014). Action video games do not improve the speed of information processing in simple perceptual tasks. Journal of Experimental Psychology: General, 143(5), 1794.
Green, C. S., Pouget, A., & Bavelier, D. (2010). Improved probabilistic inference as a general learning mechanism with action video games. Current biology, 20(17), 1573-1579.
Bavelier, D., Achtman, R. L., Mani, M., & Föcker, J. (2012). Neural bases of selective attention in action video game players. Vision research, 61, 132-143.
Mack, D. J., Wiesmann, H., & Ilg, U. J. (2016). Video game players show higher performance but no difference in speed of attention shifts. Acta psychologica, 169, 11-19.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: We will use a between-subjects design where each participant will be classified as either a VGP or a NVGP according to their responses on a video game questionnaire (administered after the behavioural task). All participants will complete a total of 14 test blocks each with 140 trials each, giving a total of 1960 trials.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Participants will be recruited from the University of West England undergraduate psychology programme. At the beginning of the academic year participants completed a shortened version of the video game questionnaire as part of a large test battery. Responses from the Psychology Data Bank will be used to selectively recruit VGP’s and NVGP’s while not revealing why they are being recruited. This covert recruiting method will be used to avoid demand characteristics of the experimental situation (Boot, Blakely & Simons, 2011). [A second video game questionnaire will be administered after participation to confirm VG-playing status.]
In line with the Bavelier lab’s current protocol (https://www.unige.ch/fapse/brainlearning/vgq/, November 2019), to qualify as a VGP a participant will need to report a minimum of 5 hours per week of action game play during the past year. Criterion for inclusion in the NVGP group will be a report of no more than 1 hour per week of action game play, no more than 3 hours per week of other game play and less than 5 hours per week when all game genres are summed during the past year.

Participants must have normal or corrected-to-normal vision and no skin sensitivities to participate. All those who participate will be compensated with course credit.
Most prior related research has focused exclusively on male participants because of the relative scarcity of female VGPs. However, our existing pool (as assessed via the VG questionnaire from the Psychology Data Bank) includes very few males who qualify as NVGPs. This is largely driven by the relatively low number of males in psychology programmes. Due to the large number of females in our psychology programmes, we actually have a reasonably substantial pool of female VGPs, and thus we intend to recruit both male and female VGPs and NVGPs with the number of males/females in each group roughly matched. We do not expect gender to be a factor in VG enhancement because, upon training both males and females on action VGs, there were no differences in the improvements seen between the genders (Feng, Spence, & Pratt, 2007). Further, other work assessing VG improvements found no differences between pre-existing male and female gamers (Cain, Landau, & Shimamura, 2012; Appelbaum et al., 2013).

References

Appelbaum, L. G., Cain, M. S., Darling, E. F., & Mitroff, S. R. (2013). Action video game playing is associated with improved visual sensitivity, but not alterations in visual sensory memory. Attention, Perception, & Psychophysics, 75(6), 1161-1167.

Boot, W. R., Blakely, D. P., & Simons, D. J. (2011). Do action video games improve perception and cognition?. Frontiers in psychology, 2, 226.

Cain, M. S., Landau, A. N., & Shimamura, A. P. (2012). Action video game experience reduces the cost of switching tasks. Attention, perception, & psychophysics, 74(4), 641-647.

Feng, J., Spence, I., & Pratt, J. (2007). Playing an action video game reduces gender differences in spatial cognition. Psychological Science, 18(10), 850-855.

q13.value: We will collect data from 42 participants, and we expect this will yield at least 34 usable participants. Experience with EEG studies suggest that we should anticipate some exclusions due to suboptimal EEG data (excessive eye or muscle artefacts). We will stop data collection when exactly 42 people have participated and will not collect anymore data regardless of the number of exclusions and/or outliers.

q14.value:
The planned study uses similar methodology as Clark et al. (2015) – the same paradigm will be employed, and the same ERP components will be assessed. There is, of course, a substantial difference in the design between the two studies – Clark et al. (2015) employed a within-participants design in which they were comparing ERP amplitudes/latencies in the same participants before/after (on-task) training; the planned study will employ a between-participants design and will compare ERP amplitudes/latencies between NVGPs and VGPs. Given the same paradigm and ERP components are being assessed in the planned study as in Clark et al. (2015, we used the effect sizes from before/after training in Clark et al. (2015) to derive power estimates (using G*Power) for the planned study. The Clark et al. (2015) study relied on task-specific training, but the magnitude of the differences observed before/after training may still be a reasonable proxy for the changes we might expect to see with VG training.

Hypothesis 1. To obtain 0.95 power and detect an effect size of 1.514 at the standard 0.05 alpha error probability we will require a total sample size of 22 (11 per group).

Hypothesis 2. To obtain 0.95 power and detect an effect size of 1.226 at the standard 0.05 alpha error probability we will require a total sample size of 32 (16 per group).

Hypothesis 3a. To obtain 0.95 power and detect an effect size of 1.231at the standard 0.05 alpha error probability we will require a total sample size of 32 (16 per group).

Hypothesis 3b. To obtain 0.95 power and detect an effect size of 1.158 at the standard 0.05 alpha error probability we will require a total sample size of 34 (17 per group).

Hypothesis 3c. To obtain 0.95 power and detect an effect size of 1.464 at the standard 0.05 alpha error probability we will require a total sample size of 22 (11 per group).

The required sample size to detect our effects for similar analyses ranges from approximately 22 to 34 total participants. Therefore we aim to test 42 participants in total as it is expected that not all data will be usable (see Exclusions section).

References
Clark, K., Appelbaum, L. G., van den Berg, B., Mitroff, S. R., & Woldorff, M. G. (2015). Improvement in visual search with practice: mapping learning-related changes in neurocognitive stages of processing. Journal of Neuroscience, 35(13), 5351-5359.

question.value:
Behavioural measures: Accuracy and response time. Accuracy will be calculated as the percentage of total trials on which participants made a correct response to the orientation of the target. Behavioural responses will be considered accurate if the participant responds with the correct orientation (vertical or horizontal) of the target stimulus between 200 and 1000 ms after the onset of the array. Response time will be recorded as the time between the onset of the stimulus array and the key press for each correct trial. 

EEG data. Continuous EEG will be recorded using a 64-channel electrode cap with actiCAP slim active electrodes. Impedances of all channels will be adjusted to below 25Ω. EEG will be amplified within a frequency band of 0.016 – 100 Hz and digitised at a sampling rate of 500 Hz per channel. Eye movements will be monitored with vertical and horizontal EOG channels. 
EEG data will be filtered with a 0.1Hz low cut-off, 35Hz high cut-off and 50Hz notch filter. All channels will be re-referenced to the algebraic mean of the two mastoid electrodes (TP9 and TP10). 
N1 mean amplitude and peak latencies. EEG activity from parietal-occipital channels on the left (PO3, PO5, P3) and right (PO4, PO6, P4) sides of the head will be used to calculate the amplitude and latency of the N1 component. Mean amplitude measures of the N1 for each participant will be taken in a 25 ms latency window around the peak of the N1 observed. Peak latencies of the N1 will also be measured. 
N2pc mean amplitude, fractional peak latency, and peak latency. EEG activity from parietal-occipital sites on the left (PO3, P3, P5) and right (PO4, P4, P6) sides of the head will be used to calculate N2pc difference waves: the difference between the activity in posterior electrodes contralateral minus those ipsilateral to the relevant popout target stimulus. Latencies of the N2pc component will be analysed using both peak latency measures and onset latency measures. To capture the onset latency we will calculate the fractional peak latency: the time at which the ERP waveform reached 50% of its peak amplitude. Mean amplitude measures of the N2pc will be taken in a 40 ms latency window around the peak of the N2pc observed. 
CDA amplitude. Activity in channels PO3, P3, P5, PO4, P4 and P6 will also be used to calculate the amplitude of the CDA component. The CDA component will be computed as a contralateral-minus-ipsilateral difference wave using the same calculation used for N2pc, but examined in a later time window (340 – 480 ms). 
LRP stimulus-locked amplitude, response-locked amplitude, stimulus-locked fractional latency, response-locked fractional latency, stimulus-locked peak latency, response-locked peak latency. Fronto-central channels (FC5, C5, FC6, C6) will be used to assess the motor-related LRP component. The LRP component will be calculated time-locked to both the stimulus array and behavioural response. For both cases, the activity will be calculated as the voltage difference between electrodes over the motor cortices contralateral versus ipsilateral to the hand used to execute the response on each trial resulting in LRP difference waves. Latencies will be analysed using both peak latency measures and onset latency measures (see above for calculation). The amplitudes of the LRP components will be assessed in a 40 ms window around the grand-averaged peak observed in the session. Baseline correction of the stimulus-locked LRP will be performed by subtracting the mean amplitude from 200 ms before stimulus onset. Baseline correction of the response-locked LRP will be performed by subtracting the mean amplitude from 1.2 to 1s before the motor response. 
VG score. Participants will complete a questionnaire that will assess their experience with several video game genres over several time frames and their responses will be used to classify them as VGP’s or NVGP’s. We will use Bavelier’s most recent version of the Video Game Questionnaire (see data collection procedures for VGP and NVGP criterion).

We will use both classical independent-samples t-test analyses and Bayesian independent-samples t-test analyses. We will report both classical p-values and Bayes factor.

Following the hypotheses described in the Hypotheses section, the following analyses will be conducted:
Independent-samples t-tests will be used to compare VGPs and NVGPs on:
A1: response times.
A2: N2pc peak latencies.
A3a: LRP stimulus-locked onset latencies.
A3b: LRP stimulus-locked peak latencies.
A3c: LRP response-locked onset latencies.

q22.value:
Initial exclusions. Experimenters will make note of any technical malfunctions, experimenter errors or participant errors that may impact the quality of data and will exclude participants accordingly. In such cases, the data will be excluded prior to analysis. 
Participants will also be excluded on the basis of not meeting the criteria for either VGP or NVGP, according to the post-experiment questionnaire.
EEG artefact rejection. Artefact rejection will be performed off-line by discarding epochs of EEG contaminated by eye movement or eye blinks (EOG), excessive muscle related potentials, drifts, or amplifier blocking. Artefact rejection thresholds will be set to ±120 µV for vertical eye channels and ±90 µV for all other channels and applied from -200 to 1000 ms around presentation of the stimulus. 
Outliers. Participants whose accuracy percentages are more than 2 SDs below the group mean will be excluded from analyses.

q24.value:
In addition to the confirmatory analyses discussed in the Statistical Model section, further exploratory analyses will be conducted:
Independent-samples t-tests will be used to compare VGPs and NVGPs on:
EA1: accuracy.
EA2a: N1 amplitudes.
EA2b: N1 peak latencies.
EA3a: N2pc amplitudes.
EA3b: N2pc onset latencies.
EA4: CDA amplitudes.
EA5a: LRP response-locked peak latencies.

As well as looking at differences in response times we will also examine differences in accuracy scores between VGP’s and NVGP’s, but we do not expect there to be differences in accuracy as accuracy is typically near ceiling for this task. 

It is suggested that more efficient basic sensory processing in VGP’s may contribute to faster responding in visual tasks. Latham and colleagues (2013) suggest that the shorter N1 latencies found in VGP’s may enable them to discriminate attended visual stimuli earlier than NVGP’s. Other evidence also alludes to a general enhancement of basic sensory processing in VGP’s. We will therefore further explore differences in the peak latencies and peak amplitude of the N1 component between VGP’s and NVGP’s. 

There is evidence to suggest that VGP’s differ in the way they deploy visual attention to central and peripheral targets compared to NVGP’s. Compared to NVGP’s, VGP’s produced a larger N2pc negativity in response to a target stimulus, although this difference was dependent on the target being near to the fixation point (West et al., 2015). It is therefore in our interest to further investigate differences in amplitude of the N2pc component between VGP’s and NVGP’s.

The SPCN/CDA component has been linked to maintenance and manipulation of information in visual working memory. Previous research suggests that the amplitude of this component becomes smaller as the search task becomes less cognitively demanding (Emrich et al., 2009; Luria & Vogel, 2011), which may be relevant to VGP’s who often engage in target-discrimination processes during gameplay.

registration_responses.q1: Neural mechanism underlying enhanced visual search performance in action video game players.
registration_responses.q2: Kait Clark, Lucy Archer, Austin C P Petrie, Alice Stephenson, Kayley Birch-Hurst
registration_responses.q3:
Pre-registration prepared by Kayley Birch-Hurst

Individuals who play action video games have demonstrated faster response times on different measures of cognitive ability (e.g. Green & Bavelier, 2003), but many changes across the neurocognitive processing chain could contribute to the ultimate quickening in response. Some evidence suggests that enhanced performance in video gamers is attributed to changes in basic early sensory processes, whereas other work has shown performance benefits involving changes to higher cognitive processes such as shifts in attentional allocation or strategy use (Clark, Fleck & Mitroff, 2011). Some studies have begun to identify neural markers associated with enhanced performance in gamers using the event-related potential (e.g. Clark et al., 2015), but to establish which components of the neurocognitive processing chain facilitates the observed behavioural change additional research is required. In the planned study we aim to identify which components of the neurocognitive processing chain contribute to faster response times in individuals who play action video games relative to non-gamers, using similar methodology as Clark et al. (2015). We plan to test action video game players (VGP’s) and non-video game players (NVGP’s) on a visual search ‘popout’ task whilst recording EEG. We will assess the amplitudes and latencies of several key ERP components: the N1 (early sensory processing) component; the N2pc (attentional orienting to stimulus); the CDA (target processing, discrimination, and manipulation of information in visual short-term memory); and both the stimulus-locked and response locked LRPs (preparation for motor response). 
The aim of the proposed study is to establish which components of the neurocognitive processing chain are accountable for VGP’s outperforming NVGP’s in visuo-attentional task, such as visual search. We will be working with a student population to identify changes in ERP components across the neurocognitive chain in a visual search task. 
References 
Clark, K., Appelbaum, L. G., van den Berg, B., Mitroff, S. R., & Woldorff, M. G. (2015). Improvement in visual search with practice: mapping learning-related changes in neurocognitive stages of processing. Journal of Neuroscience, 35(13), 5351-5359.
Clark, K., Fleck, M. S., & Mitroff, S. R. (2011). Enhanced change detection performance reveals improved strategy use in avid action video game players. Acta psychologica, 136(1), 67-72.
Green, C. S., & Bavelier, D. (2003). Action video game modifies visual selective attention. Nature, 423(6939), 534-537.
registration_responses.q4:
The following hypotheses relate to select analyses in which we expect to have appropriate power (see Sample Size Rationale section) to detect our effects. Additional variables will be measured and assessed to provide a complete picture of the mechanisms underlying visual search performance from stimulus to response; however, based on the effect sizes observed in prior work (Clark et al., 2015), we likely do not have the appropriate power to assess such ERP components with the somewhat-limited sample size of an EEG study. Therefore we include the planned analyses for such ERP components in the exploratory analyses section. The following hypotheses are our planned confirmatory hypotheses only.
H1: VGP’s will have quicker response times than NVGP’s.
There is a growing body of research to suggest that playing action video games improves performance on a range of perceptual and cognitive tasks. In general, VGP’s show shorter reaction times than NVGP’s (e.g., Dye, Green & Bavelier, 2009).
H2: There will be no differences in the peak latency of the N2pc component between VGP’s and NVGP’s. 
Faster allocation of attentional resources in VGP’s may underly the enhanced visual attention and visuospatial abilities shown by VGP’s compared to NVGP’s (Bavelier, Achtman, Mani & Focker, 2012a). However, the present study relies upon covert attention, and no significant differences in the speed of covert attention shifts between VGP’s and NVGP’s has been found (Mack, Wiesmann & Ilg, 2016). 
H3: VGPs will demonstrate differences in LRP latencies (specific hypotheses below). 
Despite earlier reports indicating that VGP’s show an increased ability to process information over time (e.g. Green, Pouget & Bavelier, 2010), there is evidence to suggest that playing action video games does not improve the speed of information processing in perceptual tasks (van Ravenzwaaij, Boekel, Fortsmann, Ratcliff & Wagenmakers, 2014). This suggests that the underlying difference may lie in the motor-response initiation and/or the motor response. 
H3a: VGP’s will initiate the motor response earlier than NVGP’s. The onset of the stimulus-locked LRP will be earlier in VGP’s than NVGP’s. 
H3b: VGP’s will initiate the motor response earlier than NVGP’s. The peak latency of the stimulus-locked LRP will be earlier in VGP’s than NVGP’s.
H3c: VGP’s will show more rapid motor execution after motor-response initiation. The onset of the response-locked LRP will be closer in time to the behavioural response in VGP’s compared to NVGP’s. 
References
van Ravenzwaaij, D., Boekel, W., Forstmann, B. U., Ratcliff, R., & Wagenmakers, E. J. (2014). Action video games do not improve the speed of information processing in simple perceptual tasks. Journal of Experimental Psychology: General, 143(5), 1794.
Green, C. S., Pouget, A., & Bavelier, D. (2010). Improved probabilistic inference as a general learning mechanism with action video games. Current biology, 20(17), 1573-1579.
Bavelier, D., Achtman, R. L., Mani, M., & Föcker, J. (2012). Neural bases of selective attention in action video game players. Vision research, 61, 132-143.
Mack, D. J., Wiesmann, H., & Ilg, U. J. (2016). Video game players show higher performance but no difference in speed of attention shifts. Acta psychologica, 169, 11-19.

registration_responses.q14:
The planned study uses similar methodology as Clark et al. (2015) – the same paradigm will be employed, and the same ERP components will be assessed. There is, of course, a substantial difference in the design between the two studies – Clark et al. (2015) employed a within-participants design in which they were comparing ERP amplitudes/latencies in the same participants before/after (on-task) training; the planned study will employ a between-participants design and will compare ERP amplitudes/latencies between NVGPs and VGPs. Given the same paradigm and ERP components are being assessed in the planned study as in Clark et al. (2015, we used the effect sizes from before/after training in Clark et al. (2015) to derive power estimates (using G*Power) for the planned study. The Clark et al. (2015) study relied on task-specific training, but the magnitude of the differences observed before/after training may still be a reasonable proxy for the changes we might expect to see with VG training.

Hypothesis 2. To obtain 0.95 power and detect an effect size of 1.226 at the standard 0.05 alpha error probability we will require a total sample size of 32 (16 per group).

Hypothesis 3b. To obtain 0.95 power and detect an effect size of 1.158 at the standard 0.05 alpha error probability we will require a total sample size of 34 (17 per group).

Hypothesis 3c. To obtain 0.95 power and detect an effect size of 1.464 at the standard 0.05 alpha error probability we will require a total sample size of 22 (11 per group).

The required sample size to detect our effects for similar analyses ranges from approximately 22 to 34 total participants. Therefore we aim to test 42 participants in total as it is expected that not all data will be usable (see Exclusions section).

registration_responses.q8.question: We will use a between-subjects design where each participant will be classified as either a VGP or a NVGP according to their responses on a video game questionnaire (administered after the behavioural task). All participants will complete a total of 14 test blocks each with 140 trials each, giving a total of 1960 trials.
registration_responses.q12.question:
Participants will be recruited from the University of West England undergraduate psychology programme. At the beginning of the academic year participants completed a shortened version of the video game questionnaire as part of a large test battery. Responses from the Psychology Data Bank will be used to selectively recruit VGP’s and NVGP’s while not revealing why they are being recruited. This covert recruiting method will be used to avoid demand characteristics of the experimental situation (Boot, Blakely & Simons, 2011). [A second video game questionnaire will be administered after participation to confirm VG-playing status.]
In line with the Bavelier lab’s current protocol (https://www.unige.ch/fapse/brainlearning/vgq/, November 2019), to qualify as a VGP a participant will need to report a minimum of 5 hours per week of action game play during the past year. Criterion for inclusion in the NVGP group will be a report of no more than 1 hour per week of action game play, no more than 3 hours per week of other game play and less than 5 hours per week when all game genres are summed during the past year.

Participants must have normal or corrected-to-normal vision and no skin sensitivities to participate. All those who participate will be compensated with course credit.
Most prior related research has focused exclusively on male participants because of the relative scarcity of female VGPs. However, our existing pool (as assessed via the VG questionnaire from the Psychology Data Bank) includes very few males who qualify as NVGPs. This is largely driven by the relatively low number of males in psychology programmes. Due to the large number of females in our psychology programmes, we actually have a reasonably substantial pool of female VGPs, and thus we intend to recruit both male and female VGPs and NVGPs with the number of males/females in each group roughly matched. We do not expect gender to be a factor in VG enhancement because, upon training both males and females on action VGs, there were no differences in the improvements seen between the genders (Feng, Spence, & Pratt, 2007). Further, other work assessing VG improvements found no differences between pre-existing male and female gamers (Cain, Landau, & Shimamura, 2012; Appelbaum et al., 2013).

References

Appelbaum, L. G., Cain, M. S., Darling, E. F., & Mitroff, S. R. (2013). Action video game playing is associated with improved visual sensitivity, but not alterations in visual sensory memory. Attention, Perception, & Psychophysics, 75(6), 1161-1167.

Boot, W. R., Blakely, D. P., & Simons, D. J. (2011). Do action video games improve perception and cognition?. Frontiers in psychology, 2, 226.

Cain, M. S., Landau, A. N., & Shimamura, A. P. (2012). Action video game experience reduces the cost of switching tasks. Attention, perception, & psychophysics, 74(4), 641-647.

Feng, J., Spence, I., & Pratt, J. (2007). Playing an action video game reduces gender differences in spatial cognition. Psychological Science, 18(10), 850-855.
